name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The session, adjourned on Thursday, September 13, 2018, resumed.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, before resuming our work, I would like to address a thought to the victims of the earthquakes and tsunamis that have caused more than 1 200 deaths in Indonesia. The Sulawesi archipelago was hit by strong earthquakes which, in addition to causing numerous casualties, caused a large tsunami. Waves up to six metres high fell on the island's capital Palu, the town of Donggala and other coastal villages. According to the United Nations, 191 000 people on the island of Sulawesi need support, including 46 000 children and 14 000 elderly people.  The European Commission has unblocked a first humanitarian emergency aid of EUR 1.5 million to help the most vulnerable and provide basic necessities such as food, housing and water. The Community satellite cartography service Copernicus has also been activated. On behalf of this Parliament, I would like to express my deepest condolences to the families of the victims, to the Indonesian authorities, and I ask you for a minute's silence in memory of those who lost their lives in these disasters. (The House was standing and observing a minute's silence) In recent weeks I have been told of a number of cases of personal attacks on Members of this House, and I would like to make it very clear that such acts are unacceptable.  Violence, verbal or physical, and disrespect cannot be justified under any circumstances, let alone if they have the effect of limiting the normal exercise of the mandate that Members have received from the citizens.  In strongly condemning these acts, wherever they may come from, I would like to express our solidarity with my fellow Members Judith Sargentini, who has been the subject of a media hate campaign, Eleonora Forenza, who has also suffered physical violence, and my colleague István Ujhelyi, whose image was offended during a demonstration in Hungary. I strongly condemn this and hope that these unacceptable incidents will not happen again.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Mr President, I am obliged to make a very short representation. Last week, as we were launching – on the platform of the Anti—Racism and Diversity Intergroup within the European Parliament in Brussels – a toolkit designed to help Member States avoid any Islamophobic content in their messaging, outside the European Parliament there appeared a huge Islamophobic poster, officially sponsored on behalf of Parliament, giving a message about immigration. That poster is against the very toolkit that we were raising, in every way possible. I request that it be removed with immediate effect.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We will verify your complaint and see if there are any grounds for a breach of our rules.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Mr President, a year ago today the sister people, the Catalan people, were speaking in a referendum, in a democratic referendum. And what did you get in return? Exactly violence.  We would like to recall that pronouncement, in honor of all those who suffered violence. And I would like to remind you, Mr President, that, as you did the other time, you should go to the new Government of the Spanish State to request information on the situation of two former Members of the European Parliament: Mr Junqueras and Mr Rael Romeva.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Thank you, Mr President. In two weeks' time, on the 16th of October, there will be a one-year anniversary of the tragic murder of the Maltese journalist Mrs Galizia in Malta. Parliament responded immediately to this terrible act, for example by renaming the press room, but Parliament also decided to create a prize in memory of Daphne Caruana Galizia, the prize for journalistic work.  As far as I know, parliament's Bureau may soon be able to discuss the agenda item of the Caruana Galizia Prize as soon as tonight. I would like parliament to be able to stand with the electorate in two weeks' time, on the one-year anniversary, so that it can go public with the decision to create this prize so that we can launch this prize and commemorate the one-year anniversary of the death of Daphne Caruana Galizia. Thank you very much!

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As you know, Mr President, how committed I am to this matter, I have been so harsh that I have also received some official protest from the Maltese Government, but tonight, for your information, the subject you have raised will be under discussion at the Bureau.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Mr President, I would like to mention that today my country, Cyprus, is celebrating Cyprus Independence. Exactly 58 years ago, Cypriot Hellenism was up in the air and with struggles and sacrifices it gained its independence by ridding itself of British colonialism. On the one hand, today we are celebrating this great anniversary of the Republic of Cyprus, but on the other hand, we are saddened that, for 44 years, a Member State of the European Union has been under Turkish occupation, under Turkish occupying troops. The President of the Republic of Cyprus has today told everyone – and in particular the European Union – that we must fight with all our might for the liberation and reunification of Cyprus, for Cyprus to finally become a normal Member State of the European Union without occupying troops, without unacceptable guarantees and without invasive rights of Turkey. I believe that you are particularly sensitive to this issue and I believe that once again the European Union and the European Parliament can send the message to Turkey that it is inconceivable and unacceptable for a country of the European Union, a full member, to continue to be divided, part of the European Union. Because only in this way do I believe that next year we will celebrate a liberated and reunited Cyprus. (applause)

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, I have asked for the floor on the same subject, so I will not repeat what my colleague has said. It's The Day of Cyprus Independence. And it is important to mention this here, because this independence is threatened by Turkey, a country that is – supposedly – in the process of accession.  We need everyone's support. We all need to remember this, because above all the essence of the solidarity and cooperation of the Member States is highlighted when we defend the independence of the Member States. (applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: It seems to me that the plenary has expressed support for your positions.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, this is both a reminder of the rules and a protest. In the last session, we were interested, as regularly, in the issue of human rights, and I would like to speak to you, based on the regulation and on the basis of the texts that this House has adopted, on the issue of human rights in the European Parliament.  All the texts agree that before a decision that grieves is made against someone, that person must be heard. I want to quote Article 41 of the European Charter of Fundamental Rights and Article 68 of the Enforcement Measures, which states that any decision on recovery is taken only after the Member concerned has been heard before by the Secretary-General. The Secretary-General robbed me of 300,000 euros and he refused to listen to me!  Ladies and gentlemen, we have passed a European Code of Good Administrative Conduct which says that in cases where a decision affects an individual - and we are also citizens - it is necessary to allow him to submit not only written submissions but also - and I quote: 'if necessary, to make oral submissions'. This right has been denied to me. It is also the result of a resolution of our Parliament on 9 June 2016.  Mr President, the parliamentary jurists who are under your orders or under the orders of the Secretary-General, Mr Welle, are currently trying to refute my legitimate claim before the Luxembourg court to at least be heard! They try to minimize its scope, to say that these resolutions have no binding value. Ladies and gentlemen, whatever the diversity of our views, what is happening today could happen to others and I will tell you, Mr President, about the situation of my assistant. There is a real judicial setback! I have the text that I will communicate tomorrow at a press conference. Your administration has falsely and falsely led the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg to believe that Parliament has no legal claim against my assistant. However, Mr. Klethi, Director General of Finance, came directly to the French court to express a criminal complaint against him.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, according to the Rules of Procedure, I have a question on the Rules of Procedure as to whether something has changed on the agenda – it is currently more of a One-minute speeches under Article 163 – or whether the Rules of Procedure of this House apply again, and always the Member must indicate, before he wishes to speak, what the point of discussion is.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President, a little flexibility is sometimes needed.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to ask you that today, 1 October, when the UN declared the Day of the Elderly, we pay tribute to them, because we are here and we all have in our country the things that we have, because the third generation, the elderly have existed, have worked for us. Today, the UN in 1991 declared the Day of the Elderly and, Mr President, please, on behalf of Parliament, to pay tribute to these wonderful people.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda, established by the Conference of Presidents pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure, was distributed at its meeting of 27 September 2018. The following amendments have been tabled: Monday: I have received a request from the Group of the Party of European Socialists to include as the first item on the agenda a statement by the President of the European Parliament on the imminent demolition of the Bedouin village of Khan al Ahmar. The declaration should be followed by a round of speeches for each political group.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, in the past Plenary, this Parliament has already adopted a resolution with a very clear message against the demolition of the Bedouin village of Jan al-Ahmar. The S&D Group re-proposes this issue on the agenda because the signals coming from the ground are alarming. The Government of Israel seems to de-eose all appeals. It continues with its plans and today, precisely today, the deadline ends so that the inhabitants have to destroy their homes and flee from there. Jan al-Ahmar is currently surrounded by the police and we don't know if the army is going to come in and demolish it. So today this House cannot be silent. That is why I call on the groups to support our request for the President to make a statement, followed by the group round. So that we may show our absolute rejection of this serious violation of human rights. For us to speak out out against this harassment and against this illegality, because no one is above the law. And so we can demand that Netanyahu not cross that red line. Because Jan al-Ahmar is not just any village: it is a strategic enclave that, if demolished, will put into check any attempt at peace in the Middle East. But I also ask you to support this request to save the school from the 180 children who consider it a safe place to study. To save that symbol of hope in which only four mud walls and tires have become. Let's re-wet the pressure because we're still in time to avoid this tragedy.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before giving the floor to those who wish to speak against your proposal, I have to say that the President's statements cannot be placed on the agenda.  At the last meeting of the Conference of Presidents, since the matter had been brought to the attention of the group chairmen and myself by the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D), I asked whether there was unanimity for me to make such a speech. There was no unanimity, the proposal was rejected by the Conference of Presidents. So I cannot make a speech, although It is my duty to support Parliament's positions, so I will always support Parliament's position, but if you want to have a debate, nothing is wrong, but a statement by the President cannot be put on the agenda.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Mr President, the High Representative has already spoken on this issue before our last session. We have already discussed this and we also adopted a resolution on the subject in the last session. I simply see this request as part of the election campaign led by the Socialists, who are making the opposition to Israel an attitude. Let's stop this, it's a shame!

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: Mr President, I would like to refer to the visit of a Parliament delegation to Palestine. We visited Palestine and this settlement ten days ago. The situation is very critical, to such an extent that, in addition to Mrs Mogherini's position, five Foreign Ministers from the major Member States of the European Union have written to Israel asking that the settlement not be demolished.  It is not just about demolishing a settlement. The situation is very critical. This settlement is considered to be a "red line" for the Palestinians. If demolished, settler settlements will expand and the West Bank is in danger of being divided into north and south. It is therefore a serious political issue, apart from the fact that the school to which my colleague referred, which is in the settlement and is now threatened with demolition, was built with European Union money. Because the political situation is very critical for the Palestinian itself, I believe that the debate in plenary is necessary.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President! I myself was part of that delegation and I can tell you that there was a great deal of joy in the village that Parliament had made such a strong statement. I find it difficult to understand why the leader of Parliament cannot say that we are behind what we have said, that we are serious, and that if Israel does not care what not only we, but the world community and international law, say, then it is a scandal, to put it nicely. It is a disgrace on the part of this Parliament and I think that Cristian Dan Preda should be too good at abusing the situation of suffering people. I think the President should make a statement.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: But that is not a debate, Mr McLy. Mr President, you do the debate afterwards. The Rules of Procedure state - and you must be aware of the Rules of Procedure before protesting - the Rules of Procedure state that one person should speak for the group which makes the request and one person who objects. I have made you speak, you were the third person in the group in favour. Prey, you can say what you want, but this is not a debate, you have to decide whether or not to have a debate, immediately as the first item on the agenda. The debate has yet to begin. So, since the vote is quite delicate, I would say do it directly with the electronic system, so let's see.  We shall put to the vote, by roll call, the proposal of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (European Democratic And Social Party) for an immediate debate. However, without the President's statement because there was no unanimity in the Conference of Presidents, I did not speak, although I remain firm in favour of the approved document. (Parliament rejected the S&D Group's request for amendment) The EFDD Group has asked for a debate to be added to the Verheyen and Kammerevert report on the provision of audiovisual media services as the second item on this afternoon's agenda, following the Cabezón Ruiz report on the evaluation of health technologies. At present, the report is only included in Friday's votes, so add a debate today and then vote tomorrow.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I propose that we have a full debate on the Audiovisual Media Services Directive, which is due to be voted on tomorrow. This directive is very important as it will regulate various aspects, from enforcing EU quotas to how many adverts can be on television in a day. Is there any aspect of our lives that the EU will not regulate?  On-demand services like Netflix and Amazon Prime will be obligated to ensure that 30% of their content is made up of European work. This legislation has also been extended to apply to video—sharing platforms, which will affect companies such as YouTube and, potentially, Twitch. They are also targeting social media services, such as Facebook, Instagram and Snapchat. Furthermore, it is creating an EU regime whereby any media service may be forced to financially contribute to another government.  This is an extremely broad piece of legislation that could be highly damaging to the audiovisual media sector. Therefore, I am requesting full parliamentary scrutiny by way of a debate this evening.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the On behalf of my co-rapporteur Sabine Verheyen, I would also like to say here that we no longer consider such a debate to be necessary. We have now been discussing all its details of this directive for two and a half years. We have received a broad negotiating mandate from Parliament to enter into informal trilogue negotiations with the Council. In these informal trilogue negotiations, we have brought together far-differing positions – in a well-balanced work of art. And we believe that we believe that another debate here in the European Parliament will not add value, especially as we will have to decide tomorrow to accept or reject the text in its entirety. Because if you were to break out a small piece of mosaic here, the whole text would collapse. And I am a little surprised that it is precisely those who have not participated in the negotiations in the trialogue, or who have only participated in the negotiations in the trialogue, in a trace.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Let us now move on to Tuesday. Tuesday: The GUE/NGL Group called for the debate on the oral question on the EU's contribution to a binding UN instrument on transnational societies with regard to human rights to end with a resolution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the United Nations has been negotiating a Treaty for four years to end cases where transnational corporations violate human rights and go unpunished. We have repeated in nine Resolutions which support this process, and the Committee on Development went a step further: we adopt a Resolution defining the elements that the European Union can bring to this Treaty. In two weeks, the Treaty will continue to be negotiated at the United Nations and the Resolution has not been discussed or voted on in plenary. Wasn't there room on the agenda? We cannot accept that human rights do not fit on the agenda of the European Parliament. On Tuesday, the European External Action Service will explain to us what they think of this Treaty. Okay, but insufficient. This Parliament must have its own opinion. I propose that we vote on the inclusion on the agenda of the Resolution of the European Union's contributions to the Binding Treaty, adopted by the DEVE Commission in July. Colleagues, most of you voted in favour of these nine Resolutions supporting this Treaty. I ask, therefore, for your vote in favour. It is a matter of coherence and respect for the work of the Committee on Development. And also respect for the European values that we defend so much.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The ENF Group has asked for the statements by the Council and the Commission on the protection of European companies against the extraterritoriality of US law to be added to tuesday's agenda.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, in recent years the United States has introduced multiple embargoes against various states, such as Sudan, Cuba, Libya and Iran. In this context, European companies have been hit hard. For example, French bank BNP Paribas was ordered in 2015 to pay nearly $9 billion in fines by the US courts. This year, however, the United States re-offended: it imposed a new embargo against Iran, claiming to give it an extraterritorial effect. Of course, the European Union has tried to retaliate, notably by the Commission's delegated regulation of 6 June 2018, which denounces this blatant violation of international law. Nevertheless, the problems continue for our European companies. For example, the French bank Societe Generale has just announced that it will pay a billion euros in fines for daring to defy the embargo against Iran. The problem is therefore not solved and I believe that the least we can do with our European companies facing difficulties is to hold a debate here in this Parliament.

name: Javier NART
text: – Mr President, that the proposal makes sense, but I think it should be limited to what is the specific purpose of the proposal.  In June this year, several MEMBERS of the ALDE Group presented to the Commission a proposal in which we showed that the very important Joint Comprehensive Action Plan — the IAPS — was at risk from the actions of the United States.  We were told that there was a mandate to the European Investment Bank and that there was an update of the annex to the blocking status, and that even the Commission was open to other measures.  What I understand is that it is important that we take into account that the problem is called what it is called, which is the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan. And, therefore, what I would ask is that the process – let us say, the resolution or the debate – be about protecting European companies in order to preserve the Joint Comprehensive Action Plan.  That's the problem and not the generality.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The Confederal Group of the European United Left/Nordic Green Left has called for the council and Commission statements on the rise of neo-fascist violence in Europe to be added as the sixth item on Tuesday afternoon's agenda. The debate should end with a resolution to be voted on during the October II part-session.  I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Mr Forenza to make the request on behalf of his group.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take this opportunity to thank this House and the many members who have expressed solidarity with me for what has happened, and I would also like to take this opportunity to express my deepest sympathy to Mrs Sargentini for the threats she has received. Briefly, we were attacked by CasaPound militants, attacked and threatened with clubs, knuckles, chains. My parliamentary assistant is currently at home with nine stitches to the head, another boy has two broken vertebrae. That is because we took part in an anti-racist demonstration. This is because we felt it necessary to wait for an Italian citizen girl, but of Ethiopic origin and therefore with dark skin, who was afraid to cross the street of her house, because it was occupied by representatives of CasaPound, who then implemented the aggression that I told you about. I believe that this House should know that in Italy alone, from 2014 to 2018, more than 100 attacks by neo-fascist organisations took place. Yet the Italian Government has kept quiet, perhaps because one of its members, the Minister of the Interior, does not hesitate to be represented at dinner with that Simone Di Stefano, whom I personally asked a few months ago, on 1 February, that he be denied a press conference in this Parliament, precisely because he is part of a neo-fascist party.  Now, on behalf of my group, I call for a resolution on the emergence of neo-fascist violence in Europe. I ask this because anti-fascism must be a founding value of the European Union. I ask this because neo-fascist violence is advancing throughout Europe, together with neo-fascist and explicitly racist forces. I ask this all the more and very concerned about what is happening in a founding state of the European Union, such as Italy.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, in accordance with what has always been my attitude, I defend the rights of all Members, I say this very clearly. In particular, I defended the rights of Mr Krivine, our former far-left colleague, whom I had found ransacking my university with an iron bar, but whose members I regretted, on the other hand, that he was not admitted to the delegation of this Parliament in charge of relations with the United States.  I am opposed to violence and I condemn any violence, wherever it comes from, to which my colleagues may have been subjected. But I think what is needed is to open a debate on political violence in general, because our colleague has shared his experience with us, but I could share mine. At virtually every public meeting I have organized, physical attacks have been committed by left-wing or far-left activists disguised as so-called anti-fascists, even though I have never had any particular sympathy for this political family, and I have never been entitled to the solidarity of Parliament.  Therefore, I do not think we can vote to have a debate that already includes, in its title, what the necessary conclusion would be. Let us open a debate, but on political violence in general within the European Union.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We now come to Wednesday. Wednesday: The Group of the Greens/European Free Europe called for the title of the Council and Commission statement on 'Humanitarian emergency in the Mediterranean: support for local and regional authorities' to be changed to 'Humanitarian emergency in the Mediterranean: the Aquarius case and the role of support for local and regional authorities'.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our Parliament has decided to put on the agenda of our work on Wednesday the question of supporting local authorities that are committed to welcoming refugees. I think this debate makes perfect sense, but it is a bit surreal to hold it at a time when everything seems to be being done to prevent any refugee from setting foot in the territory of the European Union. I take this as proof that the Aquarius, the ultimate ship chartered by NGOs which I think honours the values of the European Union, is being sidelined and that, obviously, the Member States are not scrambling to welcome - hold on well - the 58 refugees it hosts. I therefore think that it is urgent to talk about it, because talking about support for local authorities is certainly necessary, but it makes little sense if, at the same time, we do not deal with the urgency of stopping humanitarian operations in the Mediterranean. I therefore ask you to add this point, as indicated by the President.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We now come to Thursday. Thursday: The GUE/NGL Group called for the debate on the question on animal welfare, the use of antimicrobial medicines and the environmental impact of industrial broiler farming to be closed with a resolution to be voted on at the October II part-session.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, in 2007, the European Union drew up rules to protect meat chickens, or rather broilers. Now, 11 years later, this protection is still a long way off. These animals are still trapped in bare barns with tens of thousands at a time, stand day in and day out on wet litter and most chicks will never come out and see daylight. Next Thursday, on World Animal Day, there will be a debate on the protection of broilers at 3 p.m. Experience has shown that at that time the number of MEPs present will be too small to make a case for these animals. I therefore ask for your support to add a resolution to this debate. In this way, we show that the European Parliament really considers animal welfare to be important and takes it seriously. I propose to vote on this resolution in the second plenary session in October. Please support this request. Thank you very much.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Last procedure. The Minutes and texts adopted at the sitting of 13 September have been distributed. Are there any comments?

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: Mr President, I have a comment. In this minutes, we have adopted a number of texts, notably on human rights in Burma, for example, and on human rights in this Bedouin village that was mentioned earlier, and in other places.  I would like to see our Parliament one day be able to debate human rights in the European Parliament.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Soledad Cabezn Ruiz on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, public health and food safety on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the evaluation of health technologies and amending Directive 2011/24/EU (COM(2018)0051 - C8-0024/2018 - 2018/0018 (COD)) (A8-0289/2018).

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the different rapporteurs of the different groups for the constructive attitude that has made possible a practically consensual text, with sixty-two commitments. The Commission's proposal was a timely proposal. I said that when I introduced it, but it needed to be aligned with the challenges of health technologies, their access and the sustainability of health systems. I believe that the agreement we reached in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety is a good agreement because it is balanced because it focuses on the patient and because, in turn, it is respectful of the Member States which, through health systems, have to provide the right to access to health, a fundamental right. I would also like to begin by saying that this is not the first time that harmonisation has taken place in this sector at Community level. It was already done in the year 65 around safety, in the year 95 the EMA began to work and in 2001 the foundations that today regulate the field of medicine at European level were laid. And I think the results have been positive. But today the challenges are different: today we have the challenge of improving quality; research needs need to align better with medical needs, and prices, high prices also have to be regulated. These and other concerns were already expressed by both the Council and the European Parliament in June 2016. I am also aware that medicines and health technology have a view to European consumer good regulations, but this must be respectful and ultimately guarantee the fundamental right to access to health and, ultimately, access to health technology. This proposal, especially with the amendments and with Parliament's proposal, I believe that it is in improving quality, improving and aligning medical needs with research and, moreover, contributing to the sustainability of health systems; in short, to improve European citizens' access to medicines and new health products. In particular, and to illustrate this need, I would just like to give one piece of information, which is that in the last ten years, despite an increase of up to ten times the price of cancer medicines, only 14 or 15% of them have been shown to increase survival to five years. Marketing authorisation requires or evaluates safety and efficacy, but it is not your task to assess effectiveness or comparative effectiveness. There was already an attempt in 2004, through Regulation (EC) No 726/2004, to establish the added therapeutic value of medicines, but the agreement was not possible. To this day, the reality is that Member States carry out this evaluation process prior to the price and reimbursement process, which generates not only duplication, but, more importantly, the loss of the opportunity to improve the clinical evidence available, to direct research priorities to the medical needs of patients, to improve that quality of research and, ultimately, access to it. Therefore, as I said, I believe that this proposal is timely and can be positive. The Commission presented it to us justified in Article 114 TFEU — the internal market for eliminating duplication. I consider that this is neither the only nor the most important of the objectives to be achieved, but Article 168(4) TFEU allows us to take these decisions on the basis of the need to ensure the quality, safety and efficacy of medicinal products. The mandatory nature of this assessment by the Member States requires the necessary confidence that I believe the text gives, a confidence based on a high scientific quality methodology that compares on the basis of the best available evidence, which is transparent, independent and public, and that is carried out by the coordination groups, by experts at national level. And, at the same time, that it cannot prevent the Member States themselves from adapting these assessments to the specificities of their national context. I would also like to have a very important impact on what is the agreement reached on medical devices. I am aware of the difficulties and differences that there were, but we have reached an agreement that I think is positive, in an emerging sector that needs that necessary increase in evidence. The participation of all stakeholders – patients, consumers, professionals – is also guaranteed and heard. At the same time, the door is opened to voluntary cooperation in new aspects, such as precision medicine, discouraging those Technologies... (The president withdrew the floor to the speaker.)

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am very pleased to have the opportunity to discuss with you the Commission proposal for a regulation on health technology assessment (HTA), which we adopted last January. The European Parliament has shown very active and constructive engagement on this issue, leading to the adoption of the report by the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) on 13 September by an overwhelming majority. First of all, I would like to congratulate Ms Cabezón Ruiz on her timely work as rapporteur, as well as the shadow rapporteurs in the ENVI Committee, and the Members of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO). The Commission appreciates Parliament’s overall support for its proposal, including a clear and ambitious product scope on medicinal products and medical devices. While time does not allow me to comment in detail on all the various amendments, I would at least like to mention briefly a few areas of modification. First, on the issue of the national use of European joint clinical assessments, the Commission welcomes Parliament’s strong support in ensuring that joint clinical assessments will be used by Member States – and will not be repeated. The approach suggested by Parliament, of adding some clarification as to the meaning of non-duplication, should address the concerns expressed by some Member States in the Council. This specifies that the legislation should not prevent Member States from conducting complementary clinical assessments outside the scope of the joint clinical assessments. Other amendments were aimed at further clarifying the proposal, as they stress that Member States continue to be responsible for drawing their own conclusions on the added therapeutic value of health technologies in the context of their health system. The second general area I would like to comment on concerns the respective roles of the Commission and the Member States in the cooperation process. In this area, the amendments follow the spirit of the text as they aim to clarify the Member States’ responsibility for conducting the joint work, and the supporting role of the Commission. The third important area relates to the quality and transparency of joint work produced through EU cooperation. The proposed amendment should ensure the submission of appropriate evidence by technology developers as well as providing for high scientific quality, independence and transparency in the joint work. These were important objectives of the Commission proposal. Lastly, let me stress that the Commission has serious concerns when it comes to the removal of harmonisation of national rules related to clinical assessments. This was one of the essential elements of our proposal, notably to ensure a high level of human health protection. In proposing such a harmonisation of national HTA methodologies, we had actually responded to previous calls for action from the European Parliament, including to your resolution on access to medicines, which called for the harmonising of HTA tools and methodologies. I would like to conclude by stressing that the Commission welcomes Parliament’s constructive proposals and stands ready to continue to discuss and explore solutions to outstanding issues with the co—legislators. Patients are at the heart of this proposal, which aims to deliver more efficient, transparent and effective EU HTA, and this new model of EU cooperation has clear potential to facilitate better access to innovative health technologies. I therefore call on you to help make this initiative a success for the benefit of patients across Europe. I now look forward to hearing your views.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Madam President, dear colleagues, dear Commissioner, I welcome the new proposal aimed at strengthening EU cooperation on health and technology assessment, and I would like to thank the rapporteur and all my colleagues in the Committee on Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) for their close collaboration. As the rapporteur for IMCO, I have given particular interest to the fact that patients across Europe are facing disparities and delays in accessing innovative treatments due to the fragmentation of HTA systems. The IMCO opinion concentrated on improving the text in the area of the involvement of stakeholders in HTA, and we underline that cooperation between HT authorities should be based on the principle of good governance, objectivity, independence and transparency. Health technology developers should have the possibility to request an update on the clinical assessment when additional evidence from clinical practice becomes available. Finally, as regards the subsidiarity principle, while the decision on whether a drug can be reimbursed or not must remain a competency of the Member States, joint clinical assessments should be done at European level in order to shorten the HTA process, and it should not prevent a Member State from carrying out assessments on the added clinical value of the technologies as part of national or regional appraisal processes.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: rapporteur for ITRE's opinion. Thank you, Mr President. With the new legislation on the evaluation of health technology, we are taking a step in the right direction for three reasons.  Firstly, our attention goes to every patient, indifferent to where in the European Union. Thanks to this European cooperation, patients with a rare cancer or a rare disease are more likely to have the availability of a medicine that works. Subject to the necessary privacy protection for the patient and the company, Member States will have access to larger-scale research data that they could not have collected separately.  Secondly, this European clinical assessment is a good development for the producer. The pharmaceutical sector only needs one clinical test at European level, not 28. For example, the countries where there is no clinical evaluation still have access to the European assessment. The clinical evaluation of new health technology ensures that Member States are kept informed of market developments and learn whether these products are working better than those already on the market. By putting innovative developments in the spotlight, we are stimulating our health sector at European level.  Thirdly, I am very much in favour of the flexibility remaining, both for the Member States and for the coordination group that is compiling the evaluation. It remains up to the Member States themselves to decide whether there will be a reimbursement system for the new technology. Some Member States may further develop their voluntary cooperation, as is already happening today with EUnetHTA or BeNeLuxA. The coordination group retains an overview of which new technologies are groundbreaking. If we in Europe want to draw the full map of research and innovation and put the patient at the centre, then a European evaluation of health technology is the path that we must take together with the Member States.  First, Ms. Gesine Meissner would like to thank the rapporteur, Soledad Cabezón Ruiz, for her good work and all the shadow rapporteurs for their collaboration. This is a very important file that will accelerate access to medicines for patients in the EU. By simplifying procedures by doing them once for the EU market instead of once in every EU Member State, it will indeed reduce the workload of the administrative bodies in the Member States – the scientists, but also the manufacturers. However, we are aware of Member States' reservations regarding their competences. That is why it was one of my key priorities to draw a clear distinction between EU and national competences. We have managed to negotiate overall compromises on all the paragraphs which ALDE supported in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) vote and which it will support in the plenary vote as well. One of my key concerns was the inclusion of high-risk medical devices in the scope of an EU HTA. With the new Medical Devices Regulation we have just adopted new standards on the safety and performance of medical devices. Regardless of their class, medical devices must be proven to be safe and their performance must be verified. A new requirement of the clinical benefits, which is the added value of a medical device, will also have to be demonstrated. I propose to focus on strong legislation for medical products and look at the medical devices at the second stage. Although my approach did not make it entirely into the final compromises, I was very pleased to see that the rapporteur agreed to further narrow the scope on medical devices. This is a good starting point for further negotiation. Speaking generally, I think we have reached a good and solid agreement that gives a good basis for the negotiations with the Council and the Commission.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: It seems to me that the Liberals have smuggled themselves a little. But now the speakers from the political groups have the floor, first of all for the Group of the European People's Party, Mrs Grossetéte.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, after the creation of the European Medicines Agency and after the proven centralised authorisation procedure, we are taking a new step which I believe is essential in the construction of the Europe of medicine. I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate our rapporteur, Mrs Cabezon Ruiz, for her hard work in a very collective way. I would like to point out that the European treaties call on Europe, in terms of health, to allow everyone equal access to quality care and it is indeed important to demonstrate the added value of the European Union in the field of health. I could even say that the future of health, in my opinion, will be European or not. How can we understand that the clinical added value of a drug authorised throughout Europe differs from country to country? How can patients be explained that the same treatment is considered innovative, useful and highly effective on one side of the border, when it is considered to have less added value in another Member State? How do you tell a patient that they still have to wait to get this new drug already available in the neighbouring country? Make no mistake, we are not talking about a decision about the price or reimbursement of the drug, it is all in the national context. The aim is to conduct a scientific evaluation of the therapeutic added value of a new technology compared to existing alternatives. This work will help promote high-value-added treatments and accelerate patients' access to medical innovations. As the Commissioner pointed out, the national health authorities who hold the expertise will remain responsible, of course, but they must learn to work together and that is why we wanted to strengthen the collegiality of the work. A word, finally, about medical devices. This sector includes many small and medium-sized enterprises that are already facing major regulatory upheavals. We must avoid an impact that would be too brutal on this changing sector and that is why we have decided to restrict the scope a little. All of this will be a success if we can combat the reluctance of the Member States. I am sure that they will be keen to defend patients and thus enable greater European solidarity in health: this can only be beneficial for patients.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: On behalf of the S&D. – Madam Chairman, the reform of the health technology assessment system is one of the main requirements on the medicines access report we adopted in 2016. I am pleased that despite the negative signals from some Member States, the Commission has recognised the potential of the HTA system and that we will vote on the new regulation in a few days. The benefits of close cooperation between national and regional HTA bodies will ultimately benefit everyone: patients, doctors, pharmacists, health systems. The new platform will save Member States and their authorities time and money by avoiding unnecessary repetition of the assessment already made by other countries. This, in particular, applies to countries that currently have small HTA capacities. If the system lives as intended, ultimately the prices of innovative medicines and medical devices should be more affordable for patients and health systems. I believe that the European Union must do everything possible within its powers to help Member States facing rising health costs. In conclusion, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for her excellent work and hope that member states in the Council will find a way to agree on a single position within a reasonable time.

name: Bolesław G. PIECHA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on preparing this report. I approach this report dualistly, on two sides: on the one hand as a politician, on the other as a doctor. As a doctor, I realize that HTA is today the basis for optimal and best medical decisions. As a politician, I already have some doubts, because health services, health care, its organisation and funding are the exclusive domain of the Member States. I therefore recommend some caution here, particular caution in formulating very strong harmonisation on HTA. I am well aware that the evaluation of medical technologies is a multidisciplinary process that summarizes information and knowledge on the use of specific medical techniques in medical, social, economic or ethical conditions, and its use is always difficult.  It is important to strive for HTA to provide a basis for shaping a safe and effective health policy, and here I am respectfully saying that the patient should be at the heart of this document. It is also important to make the most of the financial resources allocated to health.  I have two comments. Firstly, it seems to me that the compromise would concern the possibility of constructive dialogue within the common European reports to be carried out by the Member States, as well as an additional evaluation, and possibly the use of their existing scope of work and expenditure, because it is not the case that The Member States do not prepare their own reports and do not carry out their own studies.  The second point should, however, seek to extend the transitional periods for the application of medical technology assessments mainly in the field of medical devices. This is a new, difficult, huge issue, and here I think that first we would have to deal well with drug programs, where it is simpler, we have more experience. It is worse with medical devices, here there should be a larger transition period.  Finally, it must be borne in mind that, nevertheless, health protection will still be within the competence of the Member States, and we must take this into account.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the proposal for a regulation on HTA is intended to improve cooperation between Member States. Simply registering a drug or medical device based on an assessment of its effectiveness and safety does not guarantee that the new treatment is a step forward. The diverse bodies that carry out HTAs in the Member States today often make very different decisions on the same medicines, putting patients in an unequal position, in addition to being very confused. Moreover, these decisions lack any transparency and are the work of a narrow group of people.  As I have said several times, I am very disappointed that the proposal focuses purely on clinical trials. Eliminating the economic, social and ethical aspects of the proposal is a mistake. The proposal establishes as the main authority a coordination group of Member States for HTA. Unfortunately, in the context of committee negotiations, I have not been able to enforce that patients should also have a representative in this group. I'll try again then. I will table my committee amendment in plenary, and I would therefore like to ask you to support it. I also do not like the proposed extremely long transitional period, after which Member States will not have to participate in the system at all. It should be noted that patients are waiting for this adjustment in order to ensure equality in individual Member States.  And other disappointments include addressing the issue of joint assessments of medical devices, where, let's be honest, the committee-voted text essentially means removing them from the system. On the contrary, there are certainly exceptions for faster access for patients to orphan drugs, which patients are desperately waiting for, and thank goodness we will help them in this way.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this report on the Health Technology Assessment Regulation aims to synthesize information on medical, social, economic and ethical issues related to the use of new technologies. This is conceivable, of course, and it is clear that it is better to anticipate any drift and, as far as possible, to use these innovative advances to the best of their objectives.  Unfortunately, this approach has already been applied in France with regard to medicines. These were evaluated for a decade of medical services rendered, and the result was not long in coming! Many old specialties that were generated, inexpensive and proven to be effective, were swept away, of course, because they were unprofitable. The French pharmacopoeia has thus been amputated from real little treasures. The laboratories that made them have also disappeared. Only the economic factor prevailed. Tomorrow, in the context of the evaluation of medicines at European level, but also of medical devices, which range from sparadrap to extracorporeal circulation equipment, but also of all clinical and paraclinical techniques, it will be all carers who will be checked, invalidated or even banned, because there is every doubt that independence and transparency will be questioned.  So, in our view, there is a great danger that economic interests alone will condition health in Europe. This is, of course, fundamentally unacceptable. It is as good for patients as it is for caregivers, as well as innovative companies. Last but not most, the sovereignty of Member States must continue to prevail in decisions. That is why we have presented a minority opinion in committee and why we will oppose this report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Madam President, any intervention in the field of health must aim to improve the availability, quality and price of citizens' treatments and choices. This report promotes mandatory joint evaluations and the consolidation of processes with a primary – if not exclusive – focus on the sterile deepening of the Single Market and the facilitation of industries. Health is becoming a tool for further European integration and not a means of added value for patients, improving access or eliminating distortions. Medicines and health technologies are not consumer goods. They must comply with the regulatory framework of the competent regulatory authorities and exist in favour of medical needs, with the aim of protecting human life. However, there is a need for guarantees that added therapeutic value is a real priority above the interests of industry or micro-political exploitation, because otherwise we are led to statements, such as those of the left-wing Minister of Greece, Mr Tsakalotos, to save the insurance system, that "these people will be put out of the system in a natural way". Soon "they will no longer be here", i.e. they will be dead.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Let us imagine that there are living beings from another planet and that they look at the system of how medicines and other products are going on the market in Europe. We have a European Medicines Agency – currently still in London, soon in Amsterdam – which is working very well. And as someone who wants to put a new drug on the market, you get a licence for the whole of the European Union, once you have put all the data that is necessary on the table. Then you want to make this drug available to the patient. But then, in 28 countries, 28 different procedures must be followed and additional data – scientific data – collected to answer the questions they still have about this drug. In some Member States there are even regional procedures for HTA, then the whole thing becomes even more complicated. I believe that this is a waste of resources, which increases costs. The highly qualified pharmacists, doctors who collect additional data, should instead research new drugs that will help patients better. And it also delays access to medicines. That is why it is very, very good that the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs adopted the report by a large majority. Thank you to the rapporteur, Mrs Cabezén Ruiz, to mrs Grossetéte, who did this for the PPE-DE. I am also grateful for some clarifications. We want scientific work to be done together. Whether a cancer drug extends a patient's life by three years or not at all compared to standard therapy, or only three months, is no different in Germany than in France or Spain. We are a bit different, but we are not so different that drugs have a completely different effect. That is why we can do it at European level. And the question of what is reimbursed is national competence. We made this clear once again in the committee vote. I am very grateful for that. This may also give us more support in the Council of Ministers. The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats still has a number of amendments which it wishes to table, and I would ask for your support in this. The most important thing, in my view, is: how is the decision made in the body that carries out the benefit assessment? We are in favour of qualified majority voting. Because the Council of Ministers has been arguing for a long time about how to do this. And this is an ideal instrument. After all, each country is weighted individually, but so are the people who live in that country. And that is the principle of democracy in Europe. We should apply this here too. It is also technically justified, and this will help us to obtain approval in countries such as Spain and France and, unfortunately, also in my own country, which are still hesitant. I am convinced of this after the talks. That is why I am asking for your support. We will support this report, partly because it is important for us as the PPE-DE to bring innovative medicines, for example against cancer, to the market more quickly. That is what we are fighting for.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I, too, would like to begin by thanking my colleague, Cabezan Ruiz, for her really very good work. Citizens in the European Union must be able to rely on the new blood pressure loweror or the next-generation hip joint to really meet the highest standards, in France as well as in the Netherlands or Spain. This proposal will ensure precisely that. With the proposal, we will ensure that high standards are not watered down, while at the same time taking advantage of the benefits of European standardisation of authorisation. Although cross-border cooperation at strategic and technical level has been in place for years, it has become clear that cooperation on a voluntary basis is neither effective nor efficient. It is not currently guaranteed that new health technologies within the European Union will be judged on the same criteria. But that should be the case! Quite apart from the fact that it takes a lot of time and money to have to carry out complex studies several times. By standardising at European level, we are minimising the risk of fragmented and delayed access to treatment within the Member States and ensuring better access for people in the European Union to medicines and medical products. We want to increase the quality and efficiency of interventions in the health sector and improve the sustainability of health systems. A European HTA will help in this. Finally, cooperation at EU level will be strengthened and the competent authorities will be supported in assessing the real added value for patients with new treatment options. Patients, their well-being and, above all, rapid access to medicines and new therapies are at the heart of this legislation and directly help all Europeans. In doing so, we are safeguarding the Union's fundamental right of access to medical care.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur, my colleague Cabezón Ruiz, on the excellent work she has done in densifying the European Commission's good proposal. Health promotion is a challenge that increasingly requires integrated and cross-cutting interventions. Health expenditure accounts for 10% of gross domestic product in the European Union and expenditure on medicines almost 1.5%. The increase in average life expectancy puts enormous pressure on these numbers. It's great news, but it requires more management and requires more cooperation. Technological developments are a great opportunity to improve the functioning of the internal market, to make health spending more effective and to provide better care to citizens. I am co-responsible for a resolution on this subject and I support 3 fundamental principles. It is necessary to safeguard the patient's centrality, it is necessary to guarantee the rights of privacy in the use of data and it is necessary to promote inclusion and access to these services. But it is also true that cross-border sharing of health data is essential to improve the potential of responses, on the assumption of qualification of all actors, enhanced interoperability and systematic protection of sensitive data, which should be done with tools and mechanisms developed and provided by public health systems. And that is why the legislative proposal under discussion contributes to developing the digital single market, encourages innovation and research, promotes a European it network in the area of health and, above all, contributes, or can contribute to, improving the health care provided to citizens in a generalised and budgetary-sustainable manner. It therefore traces a path that we must follow.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner! A heartfelt thank you to the Commission for this proposal. Every time we talk about health here in the European Parliament, the questions of subsidiarity and the question of concern arise swell edging into matters and competences of the Member States. If we take a closer look at Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which has already been mentioned today, paragraph 4c states quite clearly that, on the issue of drug approvals, on the issue of medical devices, the highest safety, quality and effectiveness of these products is a joint task of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission with the Member States. The present draft also speaks quite clearly of the area of evaluation of health technologies, which is limited to science, which is limited to clinical evaluation. We must mention one thing very importantly here: this is not a question of covering costs, this is not a question of ethical issues, it is not a question of pricing. This will continue to be the responsibility of the Member States in the future. What we are dealing with is the provision of new, innovative products in the medical and medical devices sector as soon as possible to patients, to consumers who are entitled to them. The current situation is that some products are being approved more quickly in some Member States. In other words, we have a dual distortion of the internal market here, in economic terms, but also in terms of the safety and health of patients in Europe. I would therefore like to thank my colleague, Cabezan Ruiz, and her shadow rapporteur for this very balanced report, which clearly identifies those areas that will continue to be the responsibility of the Member States and the area that we must resolve at European level. We need this acceleration of access, we need this security in the future, and I very much hope that tomorrow we will find very, very strong support in the vote and that we will reach a rapid decision in the consultation with the Council.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the regulation on the evaluation of health technologies may, in my opinion, lead to an important step forward in the European health sector, improving research, competitiveness and therefore the quality of medicinal products on the market. To date, a very high proportion of new medicines placed on the market do not show a clear technological improvement compared to existing medicines. Competition often plays more on the name of the drug than on its composition. Only 30% of clinical trials approved by the European Union involve more than a thousand patients and involve monitoring of more than a year, while early authorisations are increasingly common, which increasingly concern drugs withdrawn from the market. We need a permanent system that guarantees the achievement of the objectives set while respecting the principle of subsidiarity with a common evaluation methodology.  I therefore fully agree with the introduction of the European evaluation of the added therapeutic value of health technology and the harmonisation of the criteria for the clinical evaluation of medicinal products, which may lead to a higher quality of research and innovation and the elimination of unnecessary duplication. However, it is necessary to avoid the length and inefficiencies caused by the additional evaluation criteria for adaptation to specific national circumstances. In other words, avoid adopting amendments that would have the effect of watering down the objectives of the regulation in order to favour certain national evaluation systems.  A decisive role will be played by the Commission to ensure the proper functioning of the procedure, in order to generate sufficient trust between the parties in favour of the best interests of patients. For this reason, particular emphasis is placed on those amendments aimed at maximum transparency and avoiding any interference with the scientific process, which must remain independent.  The right to health is a fundamental right, important not only for integrity and personal development, but also as a key factor for social cohesion and productivity.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would also like to thank Mrs Cabezon Ruiz for her work.  Of course, the health of our fellow citizens is non-negotiable. Tackling unreasonable increases in drug prices and antimicrobial resistance is a necessity. Of course, we can only endorse the idea of a common clinical assessment of health technologies at European level. However, common public health safety issues are only a shared jurisdiction, exclusively for the aspects defined in the TFUE. This report itself recognises that the Commission's proposal is- and I quote - 'a step forward in the construction of the Union'. But can we honestly place these policies under the aegis of the European Commission, when we know how directly our health is threatened by the widespread use of pesticides, agricultural productivity imposed by the CAP and free trade treaties? Yes to cooperation between states, not just the 27 of the European Union.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to congratulate the Rapporteur on her excellent work. Medicines occupy a huge share of the health budget, but life-saving innovation is costly. However, we cannot continue to pay exorbitant amounts for a low therapeutic added value. I therefore understand that the assessment of health technologies needs to be optimised in to have a smart investment in our health.  Informed decision-making by healthcare professionals, patients and funders must be based on sound scientific arguments for the sake of the future sustainability of health systems. Cooperation in the field of ATS has to extrapolate the drug as technology and use other comparators, such as surgeries and medical devices, and can also be a useful tool for assessing the area of diagnosis, prevention, screening and health promotion programs, as well as the use of electronic health tools.  The Union's integrated approach and added value are must-see opportunities in the field of rare diseases, paediatric treatments, advanced therapies and precision medicine. With this regulation, we will move to an increasingly evidence-based medicine so that we do not have to pay more for false advances and to privilege true innovation in health.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, it should first be pointed out that the European Union has only powers to support, coordinate and complement the actions of the Member States in the field of health.  Of course, patients' access to the drug must be universal and non-discriminatory. And this is true at the whole level of the European Union. text: Mr President, health is a valuable commodity for every person and every person has the right to have access to all health issues. It is therefore the responsibility of each State to ensure the conditions in order to protect the health of its nationals and to address its problems when they arise. name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, in recent decades we have witnessed real changes in the field of medicine in general, but also in health technologies in particular. Diseases which for years have been a threat no longer practically exist in Europe, and even with regard to still-insiable diseases, we can be optimistic that they will soon also be a thing of the past.  Unfortunately, not all citizens of the European Union experience this progress. In Greece, for example, as a direct result of the austerity policies imposed by the institutions, access to high-quality health services has been dramatically restricted. Most medicines have been replaced with suspect generics, which do not meet all the high standards in force in Europe. Moreover, even with these medicines, the participation that each patient has to pay is often prohibitive with disastrous results, as treatment is not followed for reasons of inability to pay.  It is therefore easy to conclude that, despite the undeniable advances that have been made and are still taking place today in health technologies, access to them is far from universal, creating dangerous inequalities among European citizens. I therefore call for the health sector to be immediately exempt from austerity policies, since the health and life of every person must be above budgetary costs.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I can assure you that the Commission will carefully analyse and consider all the points you raised during today’s discussion – a very interesting discussion – and once again I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on this very balanced and excellent report. Let me reiterate that the Commission is ready to provide its expertise to the European Parliament and the Council, in order to support the negotiations of the co-legislators and facilitate possible compromise solutions. As recognised by the European Parliament, the proposed regulation is expected to benefit a wide range of stakeholders, including Member States’ authorities, health technology developers, healthcare providers and payers, and of course – most importantly – patients across the EU. I can assure you of the full support of the Commission towards reaching agreement with Parliament and the Council on this important file as soon as possible. Once again, I thank you for your continued support and commitment in this very interesting and demanding issue for the healthcare system across Europe and for all of our Member States.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, the Eurobarometer shows that health is one of the most important values for European citizenship, and this Regulation can contribute in this regard, because they ask us for more action. It is therefore a Regulation which can have a high European added value.  I am aware that the Commission would like us to have gone even a little further, but I believe that an important task we have done in this Parliament has been to bring this regulation closer together to make this regulation possible, because we do believe it is necessary.  As for medical devices, I understand that some groups would like to go further — as well as my first proposal — but I think the starting point and meeting point have been good. I believe that there is a pending implementation of important legislation on this subject and time must be given, and I believe that the scope that has been maintained can be an interesting first step.  As for patient participation, I think it is especially guaranteed: all stakeholders will participate not only in the network, but in the process, with the different inputs.  And finally, a qualified majority. I understand Mr Liese's position and I really share that reflection made by certain Member States, in which there is this experience - or long experience - in terms of drug evaluation and which comes especially from those large countries. But it is not a common method of approving, say, these reports when it comes to scientific procedures, and there is no precedent in other agencies. I understand, but, ... Well.  In short, thank you for all the contributions: they have all been positive.  And I believe that it is up to us now to continue to work to reach this necessary consensus with the Council so that this Regulation, which, as I say, is necessary for patients in the European Union, can finally come to light.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – I believe that the proposal for a health technology assessment regulation tabled by the European Commission is appropriate and has significant added value for the European Union. It takes another step towards building an EU in an important area such as health. In essence, the proposal aims to carry out a joint clinical assessment of health technologies at European level. Health is one of the most important values of EU citizens, as eurobarometer has repeatedly stated. As set out in the TFEU, improving health must be a political priority for the EU in all its actions, but in particular on specific health issues. The right to health is a fundamental right, not only important for the integrity and development of a person, but is also a decisive factor in social cohesion, as well as productivity. The EU's welfare system , where health systems play a key role, can ensure high EU health standards. Over the last decade, the cost of cancer medicines has increased to 10 times, regardless of their therapeutic value. On the European market, a very high percentage of medicines are not superior to existing medicines. In addition, the fact that medicinal products are considered to be a consumer product subject to market rules has helped the industrial sector, one of the most competitive sectors of the economy in the European Union, despite clear competition with the United States or emerging economies. However, the policies regulating this area must be compatible with the ultimate objective of ensuring that citizens have access to medicines.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. – The right to health is a fundamental right, which is not only important for personal integrity and development, but is also a key determinant for social cohesion and productivity. Therefore, the EU is trying to maintain high health standards in the EU, as health is one of the most important values for its citizens. The main objective of the proposal is to carry out a joint clinical assessment of health technology at European level. Health spending in the EU accounts for 10% of GDP, or a total of €1,300 billion annually, of which €220 billion is spent on pharmaceuticals and €110 billion on investments in new medical devices.  The proposal raises serious concerns about the growing difficulties of European citizens in accessing appropriate treatment in the EU, whether due to the high cost of treatment, whether due to its unavailability or poor quality of new products, which the European Parliament also highlighted in its own initiative report on the EU's options for improving access to medicines. It outlines a number of measures to conclude that we need a global regulation directive that strikes the necessary balance among all stakeholders and interests, that would focus on the patient and guarantee access to medicines and the sustainability of health systems and foster quality research and development.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: in writing. – The creation of continuous cooperation in the field of health technology assessment is a step towards better and faster access for patients to quality and modern healthcare and to reduce health inequalities. The European Medicines Agency shall issue one marketing authorisation valid throughout the European Union. Why, then, do we need to evaluate the clinical aspects of health technologies twenty-eight times?  Pooling resources and the exchange of expertise will be of particular benefit to Member States with insufficient capacity to carry out independent assessments of the added therapeutic value of innovative health technologies. However, cooperation at European level must not displace national authorities. On the contrary, support and funding is needed for capacity building in this area in each Member State.  I believe that a transparent and commercially independent framework for health technology assessment will allow scarce public resources to be used more rationally and improve patients' access to proven effective therapies.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. – Medical Technology Assessment (HTA) is a multidisciplinary process that summarises information about medical, social, economic and ethical aspects related to the use of medical technology in a systematic, transparent, non-biased and rigorous manner. This process, based on evidence that independently and objectively assesses a new or existing technology, which it compares with other medical technologies and/or the current standard of healthcare, will help to formulate safe and effective health policies that are patient-focused and aim at achieving the best cost-effectiveness. Medical technologies include medicines, medical devices and medical procedures, as well as measures for the prevention, diagnosis or treatment of diseases. This Regulation will help diversify the EU's options for improving access to medicines.  We agree that this initiative will generate savings in terms of costs and resource optimisation, specialisation of bodies in the Member States responsible for HTA, increased patient involvement in HTA processes, and transparency of decision-making regarding the availability of medical technologies. In this context, the rapid implementation of the regulation would have a major impact on patients, public health and healthcare systems.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Malin Björk, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group, Tanja Fajon, on behalf of the S&D Group, Petras Auštrevičius, Sophia in 't Veld, Marietje Schaake on behalf of the ALDE Group, Terry Reintke on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group on the implementation of the Council guidelines on LGBTI people in relation to the situation in Chechnya (O-000072/2018 - B8-0401/2018) (2018/2851(RSP)).

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a year and a half ago, the world discovered the very serious situation and the chechen horror. Hundreds of men, presumed gay, perhaps gay, perhaps homosexual, were systematically taken from their homes, taken to unauthorized prisons and subjected to torture.  Some of them managed to escape and managed to break free and tell this story. Chechnya is a state of the Russian Federation, Mr President, and that does not, of course, work for the civil rights of that country. Russian public opinion was also shocked by these events, which had been discovered and reported to the newspapers, and an independent investigation into what had been discovered and what was happening had been promised. None of this has happened, to date there is not the shadow of a single inquiry, of something trying to clarify what has happened. I would like to acknowledge and thank once again the Vice-President and High Commissioner Federica Mogherini, for the work she has done, the only Western leader who had the courage in a public statement with Russian Minister Lavrov to denounce what happened and to ask for clarity, but today we are still standing here.  What should the European Union do? The European Union must do much more than it is doing, because what external action has done, namely to have an LGBTI guidelines, is clearly not enough. Afghanistan, Saudi Arabia, Brunei, Iran, Mauritania, Sudan, Nigeria, Yemen, Qatar and Somalia, these are the countries where the death penalty still applies to homosexuals.
