In addition, countries such as Russia, such as Chechnya, such as Azerbaijan, such as Uganda, such as Jamaica, where homosexuals are imprisoned, tortured and threatened, are sometimes bullied.  The European Union has relations with these countries. economic relations, financial relations, diplomatic relations. If we really want to be the beacon of human rights and civil rights in the world, we cannot think that we are the beacon only on our own continent, but we must also be the beacon when we have relations with third countries. It must annex human rights as a prerequisite for making agreements with these countries, because if we do not do that, and I will close it, Mr President, we risk that human rights and civil rights will no longer be the beacon of leadership of the European Union on our continent too.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, the Russian Federation, including Chechnya, has obligations it has taken on itself to respect universal human rights, and it is tragic that we need to remind Putin and Kadyrov of these obligations once more. The extreme violence against LGBTI people in Chechnya must stop, and perpetrators must be held to account. Not only are there reports of concentration camp—type facilities, torture, extrajudicial killings and other severe violence, but in addition, honour killings take place and have even – very cynically – been welcomed by Chechen political leaders. It is appalling, sad and unacceptable. Kadyrov first claimed that there are no LGBTI people in Chechnya, then urged families to kill their loved ones and now suggests that media and civil society organisations are making up, inventing, the notion of LGBTI rights violations in Chechnya. We know that Russian LGBTIs and their experiences are not fake news. They are sons, daughters, brothers, sisters, mothers, fathers, friends and loved ones. No political or religious interpretation will ever change that. A number of LGBTI people fleeing the violence in Chechnya have found safety and shelter as refugees in Europe. Not only do these individuals remind us of our obligations, but also of the need to see people on the run, refugees, as individuals. That is essential and a much—needed antidote to the violent soundbites about groups of refugees we so often hear in our societies, in Europe and even in this House. We need to stand up for the people in Russia and their human rights, including LGBTIs in Chechnya. They are under threat and we need to fight for these people to be able to stay where they are in their communities, to be safe there and, if not, we need to welcome them here, now more than ever.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: author. – Mr President, more than a year ago, reports of the persecution of members of the LGBTI community surfaced in Chechnya. Since then, a lot of time has passed. The call for an independent investigation has been ignored and ignored again. The strategy behind that is absolutely clear. All those who are trying to block an independent investigation are telling themselves that the more time passes, the more likely it is that the other side is going to get tired. The more time passes, the more likely it is there is actually never going to be an independent investigation, and the more time passes, the more likely it is the other side – we – will give up.  Well, this is to all those who are trying to block an independent investigation. The truth is pretty simple. In its history, the LGBTI community has faced rejection, persecution, intimidation and torture. You probably think that makes us weak, but the opposite is true. Over the years we have endured so much, we have suffered so much and we will not give up so easily, not on the streets, not the brave activists in Russia and elsewhere and not here in this Parliament. We are persistent. We will ask for an independent investigation over and over again, and we do not forget one single case. But we will need support. We will need support from the Commission. We will need the Commission to stand side by side with the brave LGBTI activists. This is not only because we are calling for an independent investigation, but also because we need the Commission to stay credible to its commitment to international and universal human rights. So do not stay silent. Speak up in this case and defend human rights.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the authors of the question for their outstanding work. The European Union’s LGBTI human rights guidelines from 2013 help address the human rights issues confronting lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex (LGBTI) persons, in particular by setting out measures which can be used in the EU’s relations with third countries. The European Union’s diplomatic efforts worldwide on LGBTI human rights focus on the following: firstly, combating discriminatory laws and policies and ensuring decriminalisation; secondly, promoting equality and non-discrimination; thirdly, combating state or individual violence against LGBTI persons; and, last but not least, supporting and protecting human rights defenders. Depending on the country situation, the European Union is able to address the issue through a variety of means including high-level advocacy, quiet diplomacy, public statements, political and human rights dialogues with third countries, and financial support to civil society via the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. In April last year, the Russian media reported on the persecution, kidnappings, torture and killings of gay men in Chechnya. This was a serious deterioration in the already very worrying developments in the Chechen Republic. I shared my concerns with you on this matter at our last debate on this subject. In the immediate aftermath of these horrifying reports, High Representative Federica Mogherini met Foreign Minister Lavrov in Moscow, and she underlined that an immediate stop should be put to the persecution in Chechnya. The High Representative called for a full and thorough investigation into the reports, for accountability by the perpetrators, and for justice for the victims of the violence. On the same visit to Moscow, Federica met also with civil society representatives for a discussion on human rights developments. The European Union and our Member States, as well as like-minded countries and human rights organisations around the world, were swift in condemning the brutality against LGBTI persons in Chechnya. All of us have urged a full investigation into the matter. There was speculation that the Investigative Committee of the Russian Federation launched an investigation last year, in 2017, but unfortunately there has been no further news about this, or indeed of any progress in ensuring accountability and protecting victims. Since the reports of violence became public, European Union officials and Member States’ diplomats have liaised with local human rights defenders, international human rights organisations and the journalists who uncovered the persecution campaign, in order to be fully and accurately informed of the situation on the ground and to offer support to the victims. In addition, EU support has been offered to civil society organisations and human rights defenders. Such support is one of the cornerstones of our Russia policy, as set out in the five principles on EU-Russia relations confirmed at the 2016 Foreign Affairs Council. The European Union and Member State missions in Moscow discussed the issue of LGBTI persecution in Chechnya and coordinated their action. As a result, some Member States have granted visas to victims of the persecution who sought asylum. During the current year, 2018, we have continued to issue statements regularly, outlining our concerns at the LGBTI situation in Chechnya. Most recently, two weeks ago at the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) Human Dimension meeting in Warsaw, the European Union made an opening statement in which we expressed concern that the reports of arrests, unlawful or arbitrary detention, torture and killings of people in Chechnya, on the basis of their actual or alleged sexual orientation, remained unanswered. The human rights situation continues to fall short of Russia’s OSCE commitments and international human rights obligations. The European Union has also issued statements in the OSCE Permanent Council in Vienna, and at the Council of Europe in Strasbourg. We will continue to take every opportunity to call on Russia to ensure an effective and thorough investigation into the reports of abductions and killings of gay men in Chechnya, and justice for the victims of the persecution. Thank you for your attention, and I look forward to our discussion, but be assured that for the Commission – for all of us in the College and especially for the High Representative – this issue is our top priority.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, Commissioner, more than a year ago, we were discussing in this Very House the systematic violence and illegal detention of the LGBTI community in Chechnya, and the situation does not seem to have improved. Over the past twenty months, there have been numerous reports of arbitrary arrests, torture and even executions, and there have been threats to journalists and activists for documenting this violence and providing support, all in the deafening silence of the Russian Government. Finally, in August, 15 OSCE Member States asked Moscow to report on what is happening. I regret that Italy is not part of it. As Russia has not responded on time, I call on all Member States to set up an independent expert mission to monitor human rights violations.  A Union based on the values of equality and non-discrimination must condemn this unacceptable drift without hesitation and without even having to leave the borders, homophobic aggression is also on the increase in Italy. I was yesterday in the square, together with many with Angelo and Andrea, a Veronese couple attacked twice, even in the house where they smeared walls and threw gasoline on him.  The Commission is taking action to protect the fundamental rights of the LGBTI community, especially as the Italian Government seems not to care about it and some minister stirs up hatred on a daily basis. You are obsessed with the issue of security and you do not realize that it is hatred that is spreading the worst threat to the security of our communities.

name: Marek JUREK
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by People who experience inhuman treatment always have the right to our compassion and to intervene. This is a requirement of elementary humanity. If they are lonely, even more so if they are condemned, even more so, these are obvious things. On the other hand, let us briefly consider the causes of this phenomenon, which we are talking about here. Our colleague Mr Viotti has calculated a long list of Muslim countries where he sees the danger of the same situation as in Chechnya. There has been Sharia law in Chechnya for many years, polygamy is being restored in Chechnya (by the way, it surprises me that in our room, where we defend women's rights so much, we do not respond to the fact that this fundamental institution guaranteeing equality between man and woman, which is monogamy, is being challenged) and we really do not know what is going on. The problem is that the elementary differences known in the world of our culture, Western civilization, christianitas – the distinction between sin and sinner, moral disapproval and legal disapproval – do not function in this sense in Islam, and we see results. One more thing: If we are making humanitarian interventions to defend people, let us not mix ideology – as you call it – LGBTI, because we do not know at all whether those men who have been victims of such repression have defined themselves in this way.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his We must stop bowing to Putin. Now we are here one year after the last debate on the vulnerable situation of LGBTQ people in Chechnya, and we note the fact that still being abused, murdered, persecuted and forced to flee in Russia – only because of their sexual orientation. That is totally unacceptable! Innocent people are gathered together, thrown in jail and subjected to torture. More than 100 people are estimated to have fled the republic in fear of their lives during President Kadyrov's reign of terror. President Putin must now take serious serious ness about the investigation into the abuses in Chechnya that he promised the outside world, and we here in Europe must start the independent, international investigation that we have been calling for for so long. Above all, however, the EU must put an end to its dependence on Russian gas and oil, so that we can stand up freely and independently for the human rights of all people. It's about life now. All LGBTQ people who have sought asylum in these circumstances for the EU must be allowed to stay. (The speaker agreed to answer a question ("blue card") in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Marek JUREK
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Madam President, I would like to ask for clarification of the position, because you said that the only reason for the persecution in Chechnya is the so-called homosexual orientation. Do you think that in Chechnya, Ramzan Kadyrov's political opponents – the political opposition – are not persecuted? Don't they experience political persecution? In this country, which has been the victim of brutal pacification, brutal invasion, is there really no other repression? I say again: let us sympathize with people, but let us not make ideology out of it, but we sympathize with them because they are human beings.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: answer ("blue card"). "What we are discussing today is how the EU implements its guidelines on LGBTI rights. It's not a crime to be gay or to have a different gender identity. That is what we are discussing today, and that is why my speech in this House is about the rights of LGBTQ people in Chechnya.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, today we are discussing Chechnya one year on, and not as an historical event but as an ongoing atrocity. We do not know how many people are still detained in Chechnya; all we know is that their detention and torture continues for not only perceived gay men but also trans women. We know this because of the frontline responders and NGOs who are working on the ground. When news of the appalling situation of abduction, imprisonment and torture of LGBT people in Chechnya was made public, it was rightly met with strong international condemnation. The EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Ms Mogherini, was part of the international chorus demanding that Russia take action on this dreadful situation.  Yet one year on it is clear that condemnation alone is not enough. The EU must act as a defender of LGBTI rights, as it is obliged to under international law. To date, Russia has not conducted any meaningful investigations into these abuses, effectively allowing the perpetrators to carry on with impunity while victims continue to flee. The EU and its Member States must put more pressure on the Chechen and Russian authorities. We need to put concrete action behind the LGBTI guidelines in EU policy. The guidelines state how the EU can uphold LGBTI rights by encouraging states to acknowledge LGBTI—phobic violence, to work with civil society and government, to prosecute perpetrators and, of course, the EU should offer sanctuary for those who feel the need to flee.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Chechnya is accused of abducting, torturing and killing homosexual persons. This information has led to two types of reactions. Vladimir Putin has called for a criminal investigation, which is still ongoing, following the denial of the Chechen authorities. Moreover, many European political parties represented here have expressed their moral and political condemnation in this context. On the merits, it seems necessary and wise to wait for the results of the investigation before drawing any conclusions. Let justice do its job. Violence, torture and murder are intolerable acts that must obviously be condemned if the facts are proven. But please, avoid caricature. Do not make this honourable assembly a prosecutor of good thought. It's counterproductive and quite arrogant about form. You are calling for action to be taken by the European Commission, but you are simply forgetting that the European Commission has no competence in diplomacy and that it is better than ever.  The moral lessons that you keep giving to the whole world are becoming particularly embarrassing for a growing number of Europeans who would like you to look a little more at what is happening at home. These demands are not so far-fetched because we are all elected because of them.  Your concerns about the plight of LGBT people in Chechnya are very generous, but your generosity should be primarily concerned with European citizens, especially women, who are increasingly being abused. Who was concerned about the fate of these young English women subjected to sexual slavery by a gang of Pakistani barbarians? Who was outraged by the death of Laura and Mauranne, murdered by an Islamist in Marseille just over a year ago? Who cares about the anti-white racism that swells in our societies? The countless attacks on women every day in our cities are unbearable and should move your beautiful charitable souls.  The intensity of your reactions to these alleged attacks in Chechnya simply highlights the deafening silence that you systematically make yourself guilty of when it comes to defending our own.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that we have had to discuss the worrying situation of LGBTQI people in Chechnya. For over a year now, we have been told of arbitrary detentions, torture, killings, forced escapes and asylum applications in Europe. This Parliament has already sounded the alarm in various forms, with the commitment of Federica Mogherini, alongside institutions such as the Council of Europe, the OSCE, the main international NGOs, as well as ILGA, AllOut, Certain Rights and other organisations. Let us not tire of asking the Russian Government to launch a genuine independent investigation, we will not let it hide under a carpet, I cannot help but remember the activists, starting with Yuri Guaiana, who were blocked and detained when they brought an international petition with two million signatures to Russia, which called for this investigation to be launched.  The Council adopted in 2013 the guidelines for action in defence of LGBTQI people in the world where there are still many cases of serious violations. So today we are asking the Commission, according to the guidelines, to once again urge the Moscow Government to ensure that the enforcement of these purges does not go unpunished and that the problem is recognised as such.  This Parliament will continue with the fight for the rights of LGBTQI people in the world, because we have seen, how things can change. We have seen this in the recent case of the decriminalisation of homosexuality in India, but this Parliament will also continue to combat discrimination and violence within the Eu ropean Union.  I would like to remind you that it is precisely in these minutes in Italy, in Milan, that a sit-in is being held, because of the heavy physical violence of a homophobic nature perpetrated against a boy as young as 21 years old, Samuele Vegna, who will have permanent physical damage to whom, therefore, my solidarity and I am sure that of the whole Parliament goes.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Chechen society is extremely conservative, Islamic and violent. Some of the most evil IS killers are Chechens. In Western Europe, Chechens are more known for their success in the field of organised crime, in addition to a variety of attacks. It is naive to think that this society can be changed from the outside. President Kadyrov responds with violence and conservative policies. He only listens to Putin because he is afraid of Putin. And Putin is sticking with Kadyrov because he is laboriously controlling this area. Just a month ago, five Islamist children, including an 11-year-old, attacked a police station in Chechnya. All five boys died martyrdom. If Russia is fed up with Kadyrov at some point, the Russians will again intervene violently. We cannot want that. There have certainly been many serious attacks on homosexuals, and of course that is to be condemned. It is true that this is the subject of constant diplomatic attention. But change needs the support of civil society, and I cannot see that. We should try to expel as many Chechen Islamists and criminals as possible who finance these structures at home from Western Europe. We should not be complicit by tonointing their behaviour here. We should also stop supporting Islamist missionary work in Europe, such as through the Ditib. Europe, with its progressive social model of enlightenment and our wealth, can set an example for other societies. At the moment, we are giving up this without need.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, in 2017 the world learned of horrific persecution of gay men in Chechnya. 18 months later we must not forget their struggle. Sadly, the situation has not improved greatly and we should all be aware that civil society organisations are still working to evacuate people from the region. Oyub Titiev, the Chechen director of the rights group Memorial, who first denounced the attacks on gay men in the region, is still in pre—trial detention. His case demonstrates how hostile the environment in Chechnya has become for human rights defenders. I urge the authorities to immediately and unconditionally release Titiev. Ironically, the Chechen strongman leader, Ramzan Kadyrov, and officials at Russia’s Justice Ministry have the audacity to say that the rights of the LGBT community were not violated in Chechnya because there were no gays there. More than one year after the Russian—backed purges, there has shamefully been no criminal prosecutions for the deadly violence. Meanwhile, the Russian—Chechen singer, Zalim Bakaev, a popular gay icon who disappeared on 8 August 2017, has still not been found alive or dead. He was a star on the rise and the world is a darker place for his disappearance and alleged torture. We should also remember that it is not only gay men who face hostile environments and human rights violations in Russia and elsewhere. The situation of trans people, for example, worldwide, is appalling. These violations of LGBTIQ are happening in all countries, in many different faith communities, including European Christian societies and Members on the far right have failed to understand that the right—wing DUP in Northern Ireland, for example, is both a homophobic and anti—abortion party.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – "We do not have such people in our country", president Kadyrov refuted the accusations about the persecution of LGBT people in Chechnya. It's horrible when you know that at that time he had dozens, hundreds of innocent gay men systematically arrested and imprisoned in concentration camps. There are reports of torture and even executions. Since his appointment, Kadyrov has been waging a reign of terror against the LGBT community. In the Kremlin, the president of the Russian Federation, Vladimir Putin, likes to turn a blind eye in exchange for political support from Chechnya. After the international outcry, now is the time for action. I would also like to refer to the report by my Flemish N-VA colleague Piet De Bruyn, which was adopted in the Council of Europe. Commissioner, there must be no impunity for this kind of human rights violations. There must be an independent investigation and, ultimately, a prosecution of all those responsible. Ladies and gentlemen, the LGBT community in Chechnya is being criminalised, persecuted and tortured. The questions we are asking the Commission are pertinent. What do we do about it? How do we increase the pressure on Kadyrov and Putin? When I hear the debate here, I think there is broad support in this House to actually increase the pressure. Finally, I would also call on all Member States to take in Chechen LGBT refugees, following the example of our Belgian Secretary of State Theo Francken. They deserve our protection.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is now more than a year since the Russian newspaper Novaya Gazeta reported that at least one hundred men were being held in unofficial prisons in Chechnya, on charges of being LGBT people who were subjected to various tortures and humiliations. A year in which everything happened in Chechnya. And here, nothing. You're pretending nothing? We are here to denounce it because the violations of rights are clear, blatant and repeated. The purpose of this question is precisely to intervene and as soon as possible. The Eu ropean Union can no longer remain silent, without calling for an independent and transparent investigation, while the Chechen authorities continue to openly incite hatred against LGBT people. Also because of its international obligations, the Commission must establish a dialogue with human rights organisations and Russian civil society, in order to help those who have fled Chechnya and thus bring this campaign of endless violence to the fore. The Member States must also play their part by simplifying asylum application procedures for these victims, in accordance with European and national law.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: – Mr President, the public record of gay marriage, torture and secret prisons in Chechnya is abhorrent. It is incomprehensible that the fundamental human rights, that is, the right to life, personal freedom and integrity, depend on a person's sexual orientation as recently as the 21st century. I hope that these public allegations will be thoroughly investigated and that those responsible will be held accountable for what they have committed. It would also be important for the victims and their family members to have all the support they need.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, the European Parliament as a whole will condemn the persecution of homosexuals in Chechnya, adding, of course, the necessary dose of anti-Russian propaganda. Clearly we condemn prosecutions and imprisonment on the grounds of sexual preferences.  Of course, although the real cause of these prosecutions is briefly mentioned, you deliberately avoid mentioning the source of the problem. Contrary to what you might think, the problem is not Russia, but the fact that in these areas the vast majority of the inhabitants are Muslims, even with a tradition of radicalising them and armed attempts to establish an Islamic emirate in the Caucasus.  So a large part of Muslims regard homosexuality as a very serious sin and, in addition to the possible future loss of paradise, sinners also face the much more immediate risk of losing their lives or at least pre-eminences. Relatively recent are still images of the Islamists of the caliphate firing from the rooftops of gay buildings. Unfortunately, with your policy of Islamising Europe, this ill-health mentality is also allowed to develop within the European Union.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it has been a very useful exchange and I thank your colleagues for their interventions. From this debate, I conclude that we have a common concern about what has been happening in Chechnya. Violence against the LGBTI community has also disclosed the appalling situation of human rights in that Russian republic. This is the hard reality on the ground.  We will continue coordinating with Member States to support the victims and to put pressure on the Russian authorities to stop the violence and ensure justice for the victims. We will continue to pursue all the avenues open to us, and to look at how best to use all our available instruments in specific support of human rights and democracy. Just a few words about our support under the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR). In 2017, several emergency grants were allocated under the EU’s Human Rights Defenders mechanism to LGBTI persons’ rights defenders from Russia at the time of the events affecting LGBTI persons in Chechnya. I hope that you will understand when I say that it is important to maintain discretion with regard to annual support when a vulnerable or at-risk community is concerned in order to be able to continue our work. It is also very important to bear in mind the complications that receiving funding from abroad can entail for Russian organisations in view of the foreign agents legislation.  I would like to close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this, and other significant human rights issues, on the agenda.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you, Mr Stylianides, for these 2.5 hours spent with us.  I close the debate.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on international financial reporting standards: IFRS 17 Insurance Contracts (2018/2689(RSP)).

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, the insurance industry fulfils a central role in the European economy, and European insurers play an important role globally. Insurers are important long-term investors. This is why, in November 2017, the Commission asked the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group, or EFRAG, to carry out a comprehensive impact assessment to inform the EU’s decision on a possible endorsement of the International Accounting Standards Board’s International Financial Reporting Standard 17 for insurance contracts. The Commission specifically requested an assessment of the consequences of the standard on financial stability, taking into account the joint implementation of International Financial Reporting Standard 9, on the competitiveness of the European insurance industry, on the impact on the insurance markets across Europe, and on long-term investment.  In the meantime, the Commission launched two separate initiatives on the consequences of IFRS 9 on long-term equity investments and possible alternative methods to the mark-to-market valuation of long-term equity investment portfolios.  In response to the Commission’s request, EFRAG launched an impact assessment, including a field test of the IFRS 17 standard. The Commission acknowledges that the scope of the field test is limited. This is a necessary trade—off designed to secure a realistic implementation timeframe ahead of the implementation date of 1 January 2021, set by the IASB. Constituents have raised technical issues. EFRAG is currently considering these issues in its endorsement advice and has referred six implementation concerns identified as part of its impact assessment on the IASB. Furthermore, with a view to sustaining the implementation of IFRS 17, the IASB sets up a transitional resource group on insurance contracts, which is expected to channel the interpretation and implementation issues arising from the standard. The IASB is expected to consider potential amendments to IFRS 17, as well as a request for deferral of the implementation date, at its October meeting. As part of the endorsement procedure laid down in the International Accounting Standards Regulation, the EU is only empowered to endorse, refuse or carve out parts of a standard. The Commission therefore encourages the insurance industry to report this implementation challenges exhaustively to the IASB transitional resource group, and to actively develop realistic solutions, if necessary by devising targeted improvements to IFRS 17 when outstanding issues cannot be resolved through the interpretation of IFRS 17. With a view to securing the consistent implementation of the standard following the endorsement decision, the European supervisory authorities and the European Central Bank participate in the endorsement process as observers.  Finally, as part of its fitness check on public reporting, the Commission will specifically consider the potential inconsistencies between IFRS 17 and the existing EU reporting framework applicable to the insurance industry, including the Insurance Accounting Directive and the introduction of the Solvency II prudential regime in 2016. The Commission expects to report the findings from the fitness check by the second quarter of 2019, so as to secure its capacity to undertake any necessary action before the implementation date of IFRS 17 on 1 January 2021.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, this motion for a resolution is about International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) 17 for Insurance Contracts. These standards are a fundamental change in the accounting for insurance contracts, bringing the benefits of more consistency, transparency and comparability. This motion for a resolution is the result of the permanent teamwork set by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) after the financial crisis to focus on the reform of the IFRS. IFRS issues are no longer secondary business for ECON and Parliament.  I would like to thank all members of this permanent team and to the other members of ECON who contributed to this motion. In this motion for a resolution we underline the effort and costs needed in order to implement IFRS 17, which are significant. Unfortunately, the signals that we have received from insurance companies that have started to prepare the implementation of the IFRS 17 confirm the difficulties of this implementation. The effort, time and cost in human resources have been underestimated. Our technical adviser, the European Financial Reporting Advisory Group (EFRAG), has already identified several issues raised by IFRS 17 during the drafting of its endorsement advice, such as the level of aggregation, the contractual service margin, and reinsurance.  The final endorsement advice is expected in December 2019. We regret again that no field test has been developed to examine the potential effects that IFRS 17 might have on financial stability and competitiveness in the financial markets. We ask the Commission and EFRAG to consider carefully all the signals sent by the insurance sector and to deliver clear assurances in respect of these signals through the endorsement advice. The Commission and EFRAG should assess whether the current implementation timeline of IFRS 17 is appropriate.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, with regard to the accounting standard 17, this Parliament calls for your vigilance. We are talking about experience. When we adopted the equivalent accounting standard for banking, the so-called IFRS 9, we finally discovered - nine months after this standard came into force, thanks to a study by the European Systemic Risks Committee - that our intuition, our vision that the introduction of such a standard might perhaps weaken long-term investment. , was well founded. We call for the same vigilance with regard to the insurance sector and therefore ask not to repeat the introduction of an accounting standard, this time IFRS 17, which would also risk undermining the long-term investment that we know is so much needed for the European economy. We need to learn another lesson from experience, from what insurance companies have experienced through the implementation of the Solvency II Directive. Everyone agrees that this is now useful legislation, adapted to the insurance business, but it has only been able to come into force through a long iterative process. The more I consider the concerns about the IFRS 17 accounting standard for the insurance field, the more I think that the question of the timing of implementation — beyond a few adjustments that may need to be asked by the international authority, the IASB, to revise its copy — is essential. To do this, the Commission must take full account of both the resolution we are going to adopt next Wednesday but also, of course, the EFRAG, which works under the enlightened authority of its President. Allow me, Mr Vice-President, to draw your attention to an essential point both of the oral question we are asking and of the draft resolution which - I hope - we will vote on: to verify that at least this accounting standard of course contributes to the financial stability and competitiveness of the insurance sector, but also to the cross-cutting objectives that the European Union must now pursue in each of its legislations. , that is, this standard contributes to the definition of the public good, the sustainability of our economies, long-term investment and the achievement of our climate change goals.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, insurance undertakings play an important role in the real economy. Let's take into account that the largest insurance companies recorded revenue of $27.6 trillion this year and profits of $1.5 trillion. One understands that they play an important role and of course, if something goes wrong, this creates risks to financial stability in Europe and to long-term investment in the economy itself. The International Financial Reporting Standard (IFRS) 17, from what we have seen, will be implemented in two and a half years, from 1 January 2021. But there are too many thoughts and criticisms as to whether the insurance market itself is really ready, whether insurance companies themselves can deal with the problems that exist.  Of course International Standard 17 will contribute to greater transparency and comparability, but it is complicated. And insurance companies, as they act and work, see that significant training of executives is needed, changes are needed, investments are needed, measures are needed. It appears that 67 % of large insurance undertakings are ready, but only 10 % are ready for small insurance undertakings. Therefore, the whole debate on whether there should be an extension and an adjustment, I think, is mature and is rightly taking place here in our European Parliament.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, international agreements on how to report to investors and other stakeholders are crucial in a world where borders are actually becoming increasingly blurred. The insurance sector is lagging behind. I therefore welcome the fact that IFRS 17 will be introduced internationally in the coming years. This will inevitably entail costs. Harmonisation and progress are not free at all. But I believe that it is worth it, that the benefits will outweigh the costs and that the insight and comparability will contribute to a much more efficient market. Is ISFR 17 perfect? No. Are there standards that are optimal for everyone? No. But that does not, as far as I am concerned, removes the fact that we are striving for standards that work for the European market and for European companies. That is also why EFRAG is currently investigating the effects of IFRS 17 across Europe. On the basis of that opinion, the Commission and the co-legislators can then decide whether postponement is justified and, if so, under what conditions. Parliament's resolution makes a number of suggestions for further research to the EFRAG. We await these results with full confidence. New agreements will have to be made at the highest level, internationally. I assume that the concerns that have already been identified by the EFRAG and the European market parties will be taken into account. If it is indeed a substantial adjustment of the standard at international level, then, as far as I am concerned, we must also be prepared to grant a postponement in Europe in order to allow for a very careful transition.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, after a hastily implemented IFRS 4 Standard that has left out the measurement of liabilities, this standard seeks to close this loophole by imposing rules that should be applied from 2021 by large insurance companies. In fact, this standard touches on a sensitive point of undertakings, since the assessment of the lideiresponsibilities of insurance contracts, with particular emphasis on long-term contracts, will impact not only the clearance of the profits of insurers, but also the levels of capital necessary for prudent management to cope with any unforeseen event. It is no accident that the big lobbyists are already on the ground, criticising the standard for the high costs of its implementation and its reduced effects. They know what they're talking about. For our part, we also have doubts about the capacity of these standards, which do not touch the essentials, that is, they do not solve the problem of conflict between the private interest and the interests of citizens.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, this reform of accounting standards in insurance companies is mainly about the companies themselves, but above all about investors. By 'investors', of course, we do not mean small investors, who usually have no idea where their savings are invested, but large international funds, whose lives will clearly be made easier by these new standards.  I have no doubt that there are very specific benefits to this reform, but at the same time I believe that the adoption of these standards by the Member States must take place on a voluntary basis, given that this issue concerns national sovereignty and the possibility that States should have to set their own rules in their internal market.  If and when it is estimated that these standards will indeed contribute to the better functioning of the markets, but also to the protection of policyholders and investors, then they can adopt them, thus attracting foreign investment. However, if it is compulsory to adopt the standards, without taking into account the specificities of each country, this measure will create more serious problems than it expects to solve.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start by welcoming the resolution on the international financial reporting standard IFRS 17, which is a response to the potential contradictions between it and European legislation on insurance contracts, and in particular between the new standard and the Union's legislative body on prudential matters.  On the one hand, I share the view that it is necessary to ensure that IFRS 17 does not represent a constraint for small and medium-sized enterprises, while defending high-quality information and publication and including the sustainability of long-term objectives in line with the Paris Agreement. On the other hand, I believe that we must guarantee and support an IFRS 17 standard that is more favourable to the European public good, with the European Parliament increasingly involved in its implementation.  Therefore, I support calls for the Commission, the European supervisory authorities, the European Central Bank, the European Systemic Risk Committee and the Advisory Group for Financial Information in Europe to closely monitor the implementation of IFRS 17 in the European Union, prepare an ex post impact analysis by June 2024 , present this assessment of the European Parliament and act in accordance with the opinions of the European Parliament.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will say at the outset that I am not in favour of broadening the reports, the new reports. Why? Because we are not yet able to use the data that we have already collected. On the other hand, I am opposed to over-regulation of market elements that are related to services, because I believe that they are developing worse. On the other hand, I understand and share this general point that standards need to be raised, first of all by thinking about people, about the recipients – in this case insurance services. However, I believe that this must be done extremely gently, so that this market is not damaged, it is not turbo-charged, also from the business side.  I would have two questions. Commissioner Ansip answered one question, so I will not go back to that. The second question was addressed to the rapporteur à propos timetable. Unfortunately, the schedule, as I understand it, is somewhat at risk. That is what I pointed out in my last speech.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for their interest in International Financial Reporting Standards: IFRS 17. The Commission will continue to monitor closely the endorsement of the standards, taking into account the European Parliament’s concerns, with a view to ensuring that IFRS 17 is conducive to the European public good and that its implementation does not put any undue strain on the European insurance industry.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you very much, Mr Vice-President, for such a categorical and at the same time brief statement. I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Wednesday 3 October 2018.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Eva Kaili, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on distributed ledger and blockchain technologies: building confidence in fund flows without banking intermediation (O-000092/2018 - B8-0405/2018) (2017/2772(RSP)).

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Eva Kaili and the honourable Members of the European Parliament for this question about distributed ledger technologies and blockchains, as well as the motion for a resolution. The European Commission shares the view that distributed ledger technologies and blockchain—based developments are an opportunity for industry and public services in Europe. This will allow rethinking of information systems and processes promoting user trust while ensuring compliance with the protection of personal data and transparency. These technologies have the potential for more efficient delivery of products and service across organisational boundaries and borders. I had direct experience of that potential in June when I attended a blockathon where 11 teams of coders developed ways to fight counterfeiting. Blockchain can provide an electronic chain of custody for each and every piece of intellectual property.  The Commission is working to seize the opportunities, address the limitations and define policies that will promote the uptake and development of blockchain based applications in Europe. To reach scale, 26 EU countries and Norway have agreed to work together to set up the European Blockchain Partnership. Its aim is to develop a coordinated European response that guarantees interoperability and avoids fragmentation. Another objective is to create a European blockchain services infrastructure to support cross—border public services with the highest standards of security, privacy and energy efficiency. The partnership is now examining which cross—border digital public services could benefit most from such infrastructure. Examples include the exchange of data for moving goods, duty suspension, digital identity and VAT collection.  The first EU-wide services will be provided over the European blockchain services infrastructure by next year. Principles of governance and other conditions will be specified by the end of this year.  With the help of the European Parliament, we have also launched the EU blockchain observatory and forum to help us identify and overcome obstacles in blockchain innovation. They organise online community building, workshops and blockchain focused events across Europe. Their work aims to stimulate a competitive blockchain environment and the conditions of legal certainty that are needed to sustain investments in distributed leisure technologies and blockchain applications across the European Union. Thank you for your attention, I am looking forward to the discussion. (Applause)

name: Eva KAILI
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to thank Commission Vice—President Ansip very much. I am happy to present the resolution on distributed ledger technologies and blockchain, the first one on this promising technology. This resolution has already achieved important political goals. It has become a reference point for other reports related to blockchain technology in this House and it has provided guidelines to the Commission, along with policy directions, preparing the ground for further action. It also provides a solid framework for legal certainty, not only in Europe but also beyond, and of course it has received publicity worldwide. Blockchain is a groundbreaking technology that promises to improve efficiency, reduce costs and friction, and increase transparency and trust in a wide range of sectors, such as supply chains, financial services, energy, transportation, health care, education, and even copyright and the creative industries, by giving citizens back control of their data. Blockchain also has strong potential to improve the quality of public services, and, as an instrument or indeed a platform, to increase efficiency between the state and the citizen in relation to smart contracts, public documents, avoiding duplication, certificates, licences, land registries and even voting. Blockchain-based applications could also potentially help to fight fraud and tax evasion. I am pleased, too, to announce that blockchain has united this House, as all the parties in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) voted in favour of the resolution under the principle of being technology neutral and innovation friendly in Europe. One of the core messages of our text was to signify that the European Union aspires to become the global leader in the fourth industrial revolution. Here I must underscore the great contribution and work of Commissioner Gabriel in this direction, and thank her for supporting the funding of pilot schemes in a broad EU blockchain alliance of Member States. I would also like to thank Vice—President Ansip, since he is one of the people who have led by example in his country, making Estonia one of the most advanced countries in Europe in the digital era. On behalf of the ITRE Committee, allow me to deliver the following oral question to you Vice—President. Distributed ledger technologies (DLTs) and blockchains have not only shown great potential in improving existing value chains, but also create new value chains that reduce intermediation costs and transactional friction, and that remedy trust issues, monitoring problems and transparency concerns. The applications of blockchain are numerous and encompass a wide range of sectors. Energy grids, health care, the financial sector, supply chains, transport, education, the creative industries and the public sector are just some of the possible fields. In terms merely of transaction fees, we have an OECD study to the effect that EUR 130 billion in hidden fees is the cost in Europe alone per year. In order fully to grasp the potential of DLTs in the spirit of technological and business—model neutrality, we need a better understanding of their key underlying features, such as decentralised distributed databases, disintermediation, the immutability of data, ad permission and permission—less applications, as well as the technological possibilities they offer in areas such as smart contracts and funding for SMEs through Initial Coin Offerings (ICOs). However, in addition to their potential, DLTs also raise concerns about data protection and in relation to the General Data Protection Regulation. Cybersecurity, interoperability, new sources of fraud and environmental issues are among these concerns. How is the Commission planning to provide the environment of legal certainty that is needed to boost DLTs and blockchains in Europe; and what initiatives would the Commissioner undertake to create a competitive blockchain ecosystem in the EU? Let me just say that technology is neutral. How we use it depends on us. We are innovation friendly and I think this is demonstrated by this resolution and the great support it has received thus far.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, thanks to Eva Kail and Commissioner Ansip, it has been truly inspiring to work on the blockchain resolution in this House. It was great how enthusiastically the various stakeholders and members of parliament participated in this work. Europe is clearly a pioneer in blockchain technology, and this is clearly an area where we have a very strong basis for developing into a world leader in the future as well.  It should be noted that blockchain is still an evolving technology, but it has very great potential. What we discussed very much during that work was that we must ensure that Europe has a very pro-innovation legislative environment – legislation that would encourage innovation in the sector and also encourage investment.  In particular, we are trying to find points where we would have legal needs. Often, of course, companies say that do not just start making any legislation, but on the other hand it is very important that we have a European reference framework from the outset, because if we do not make a European reference framework, it often leads to Member States starting to take their own action and that would lead to the fragmentation of the digital single market again. It is therefore important that we have an immediate Europe-wide approach to this new technology. I am very pleased that all the Member States are now working on this and are working together to find areas for development where blockchains could be used together. Similarly, the Commission has set up this blockchain observatory, where experts are also carrying out this same mapping work.  It is now also important to invest sufficiently in research and product development in the sector. The Commission has already invested EUR 80 million to date, with the aim of investing an additional EUR 300 million in blockchain technology over the next few years. It is, of course, a very important contribution for the whole of Europe: investment in research and product development, and ensuring that we have legislation that encourages innovation and investment.  We must also ensure that companies have a certain legal certainty when they start investing in this new technology. Among these applications, smart contracts, among others, have been on display. In other respects, legislation must also be assessed in order to have sufficient legal certainty.  There is a great deal of talk about cryptocurrencies in the context of blockchains, but it should be noted that we have a very large number of promising other sectors that can take advantage of blockchains: transport, energy, healthcare and different supply chains, that is, it is a very potential technology. Now we need to ensure that our legislation is technology-neutral and innovation-encouraging and that companies have sufficient legal certainty when they go into the sector to invest.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, all technologies pose difficult question when they arise: how to take best advantage of the new tools, but avoid potential pitfalls that might come along? Blockchain and DLTs are part of the great digital transformation, together with the development in the artificial intelligence, cloud computing, social media and very high connectivity, these new technologies will radically change the way we live. Challenges are often debated here in the plenary, and they are many: security, privacy, trust and copyright, they are familiar to us MEPs. But some problems might have a straightforward solution. DLT will make sure that information moves at speed, but that it remains secure and that transactions cannot be manipulated as each party sees modifications. One promising application is in the field of copyright. A distributed ledger can give both artist and art consumers a better, more transparent method of knowing who made which piece of digital art, and I want to see applications in Europe for example on renewable energies and electrical charging for cars. But there are other more wicked problems: take for example trust in society. How will DLT increase trust if new financial instruments based on the technology are volatile and not very transparent? Moreover, how do we ensure that core functions of society, such as taxation or prevention of crimes, can still function in a world where data is not centralised? Blockchain technology developers need to answer these questions when developing the technology and applying it, hopefully destroying some old thinking and models of the way of life today. I’m also curious to see how old companies will find new ways to integrate this technology. Public sector and governments must also change and learn to do things better with the new technologies, and I’m very happy that the Commissioner took up these concrete ways in Europe as well. So Madam President, I support the active role that the Commission has taken, and Parliament supported it in order to get involved in the possibilities offered by blockchain and DLTs. The EU Blockchain Observatory and Forum is now up and running. We as a society need to adopt a strong but soft approach to new technological possibilities. We must not curb innovation, but set the framework for a legal and trustworthy environment. We need to learn ourselves and be fast to recognise new situations and effects, and take corrective measures if need be.  (Applause)

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, "distributed ledger" is a system that allows us to trust data, money and software. Blockchain is a type of it and will have a huge impact on our economy. This is very positive because it can lead to more efficient markets, cost savings and better resilience to cyber attacks. On the other hand, the system is still in its infancy. It is therefore important, as far as I am concerned, that we look very carefully at the challenges that this system poses. I think this resolution is a very good first step. I'm happy with that, too. This technology is also widely embraced by the financial sector. However, we simply cannot afford to take risks, particularly in this sector. As far as I am concerned, there is no room for a quick-and-dirty approach. We must not close our eyes to the risks of the new digital systems. When and how, for example, can it be seen whether it is being abused? How are we going to protect our citizens of Europe from this? This calls for rules to prevent money laundering or tax evasion. Understand me: I am very much in favour of this technology and really believe in it. I do think that European legislation is needed to enable innovations such as blockchain on the right scale. As far as I am concerned, the legislation must be facilitating. It must not stand in anyone's way and provide the right opportunities for the European market, because that is the only way we can compete with the most innovative continents on earth. Investors and consumers have a right to secure digital systems. The Netherlands is at the forefront of this by creating an environment in which experts from the government, business and the blockchain sector work together. I am proud of that and I would like to give the Commission this consideration as a kind of encouragement. The foundation of the application of blockchain has been laid. Now we need to continue to work on this in a safe, responsible way.

name: Jakop G. DALUNDE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you to the Commission and the rapporteur for acting so forcefully on this issue. It is really important that Europe shows leadership here because blockchain, or distributed databases, is a technology with tremendous potential and with a variety of possible application areas. Technology can become a safe and effective alternative to encryption to protect personal data and something that will become increasingly important in the future. With blockchains, we also have the potential to democratize energy markets, for example. Individual households will be able to produce green electricity and easily sell their surplus to the grid. There is also the potential to tackle corruption around the world. By decentralising systems and data, we reduce the ability of corrupt officials to exploit their position for their own benefit. The system itself makes it impossible. Blockchain has the potential to revolutionize many areas. By now putting this issue forward, we are increasing the chances that Europe will not fall behind in this transition. If we are to take advantage of the opportunities offered by blockchain, Europe must be at the forefront of that development, for which I am pleased that we are now acting in favour.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, I would also like to begin by thanking the rapporteur. Block chains and DLT are a promise over ten years old, but so far there is a lot of discussion about the endless applications and the ones we know best are applications in virtual currencies, for example those in financial markets and so what we have seen, in a way, is disastrous, fraud, extreme fluctuations of a safe haven for tax evasion and money laundering. Blockchain and DLT, more than a significant technological innovation are, in fact, a social and organizational innovation because it is about dispensing with intermediaries, counterparties and often even the State itself.  Now that we are thinking of applying to other sectors - such as energy, education and others that have already been mentioned here - I believe that we should also talk about the concerns and why we ask for legislation and the need for legislation in this regard. In the first place, how to ensure transparency, how to ensure data protection, how to ensure regulation, if we want better public services? How can we have better public services and ensure that there is no elimination of what should be the purpose of these same public services?  That is why legislation is necessary to ensure that it is not repeated in other sectors and in the promises that have existed for more than ten years what has happened in the financial system and with virtual currencies. Yes, they can be a very useful tool for our society.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today's subject is certainly particularly exciting because we may be faced with the dawn of a paradigm at least different from what we are used to living.  We are all aware of how much information is the new gold today, and what it means to be able to control, manage, transform and use it according to the purpose to be pursued.  The distributed register, that is, more commonly the blockchain and its brothers, represents a beautiful technology, which has in itself a very positive promise of change and the resolution we vote on tomorrow contains numerous elements of analysis and push. No one is able to say today whether this protocol that allows unimaginable advances in terms of traceability, recognition, disintermediation and therefore peer trust, can ever be the new paradigm on which to base a new form of society: DLT are a terrain still to be explored in all its dimensions. Today the value chain is often complicated, intricate by a globalization that has created countless levels, many intermediates and therefore many different forms of cost control and other social effects.  Technologies like these, whether called blockchain or otherwise, certainly allow you to imagine new information models, distributed control and rapprochement between the production phases of goods and services and their use and consumption. I am therefore encouraged by the existence of these frontier technologies and the fact that they are being talked about here, but at the same time I am tremendously fascinated by them, but sometimes frightened, so I never want to close my eyes, waiting uncritically and passively to see how far we can go.  I strongly believe that the modern and scrupulous legislator must be maniacally curious and attentive so that we never have the desire to know well what is having to come out of the world again, in order to be ready to legislate on time and in full knowledge. We must therefore be able to conduct digital technologies with common sense, without suffocating them with too many rules or standardisation too much in advance, but also without ever losing control of them, so as not to be more or less aware of ourselves as victims. It applies to blockchain today, but it applies to all that storm of technological innovations on the horizon, artificial intelligence, the Internet of Things, bioprinting, the future that is being explained in a very near tomorrow. The text we are debating today certainly emphasises many positive dimensions, such as the potential in terms of traceability of ingredients and components, control of ownership and identity by opening up models of bottom-up participation in decisions and their formation or equal exchange of goods and services. In this last sector, I too have been wondering for years how we can account for energy exchanges in a decentralised production model, and I am very pleased that the Commission has positively accepted my pilot project proposal for the second year to study the feasibility of blockchain technologies in peer energy exchange. But another area that I would really like to see a commitment from everyone is to investigate the potential use of DLT for environmental monitoring and therefore the possibility for all citizens to participate in a distributed emission control system of all the plants that today load our air with particles and pollutants of various kinds , slaughtering our loved ones in a now ubiquitous way. Sustainable and equitable development certainly passes even today for digital technologies, but first we put them at our service, the sooner we curb their potential drifts. Man must always be at the center without putting technological Ferraris in the hands of a company without a license. If these technologies help these objectives, and it is our job to make this happen, then I am the first supporter of them, and that is why I am particularly proud that last week the government of my country also joined the European blockchain partnership and filled an incomprehensible absence on the curtain of the future.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, Commissioner, distributed registers and block chains are promising technologies, which could change our use of registers and their data. However, your enthusiasm and the sudden enthusiasm of the European institutions give the impression of an irrational runaway, perfect for new discoveries. My intention will therefore be to encourage you to be more cautious and temperant. Many parliamentarians see only the positive aspects of this technology, without seeing its limits, especially with regard to block chains - because the real revolution in the field of registers is the use of block chains. These allow to certify the register and avoid going through intermediaries to access it. However, this technology is not without criticism. Thus, the use of work evidence in the mining process involves consuming a gigantic amount of resources for very low real use. The mining of bitcoin consumes as much energy as Austria: imagine if hundreds of other registers had to be mined! In the long run, the size of the registers is intended to become exponential and will require that users, or "minors", have enormous technical means for the system to work. This also raises the problem of data retention time: can a block chain keep the data forever without the need for a centralized archiving registry? The independence of minors is also a constraint because block chains can only be certified if the majority of minors do not form a cartel. How can we control it? Finally, if the number of minors is today large and allows the operation of this technology, it is thanks to the remuneration of these through cryptocurrencies. So how will the remuneration of minors in a public service be made? Many other examples could demonstrate that the technology of distributed registers, and especially of the block chain, is still unspetura. Until the problems of energy efficiency and an effective alternative to proof through work have been solved, it will be foolhardy to want to offer these technologies to all parts of society. What we are therefore advocating is to invest in research, as always and as proposed, and to let the Member States legislate on their territory. Let us give researchers and time the privilege of demonstrating that these technologies can revolutionize our world.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is, in a way fascinating, to see this phenomenon, how your MEPs, commissioners, bureaucrats cannot sleep peacefully when something arises without their supervision, like their scabies, to put them in another area of life that they are not regulated by. But no and again no – there is no need for it! This technology is developing very well without you. I have the impression that some of you get up in the morning, they wonder what would spoil here today. There is no need for this. If you're going to rummage with something that works well, you can only spoil it. This technology was created in a sense precisely so that no one could comb in it, that it is independent of governments, that it is resistant to surveillance, that it ensures anonymity, and so on. So take care of your affairs, do not bury in things where no one asks you to bury.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, block chain technologies and progressive encryption applications aim to increase confidence, control and transparency in a set of processes that are increasingly complex and fundamental in the new digital society. But this impact is not automatic. The technological implications and their applications are not neutral and therefore we have a job to do. We need to ensure that new solutions based on digital innovation incorporate the values and civilizational principles that we develop and share in the Common European Area. It is in this context that the questions raised by the rapporteur and my colleague Eva Kaili to the European Commission make perfect sense and require a thoughtful and rapid response. We need to be competitive on a global scale, also in these technologies, but this competitiveness cannot be achieved at any price. No, it's not true that it's all done. There's a lot we have to do. It must be developed within a framework of legal certainty and robustness in relation to the control of cases and the risks of misappropriation of power without proper legitimacy.  The concept of multiple and self-regulated process does not nullify the risks of induced centralization or bias. These risks exist and have to be proactively monitored and fought. Data protection, cybersecurity, interoperability or fraud prevention are areas where the regulatory and guarantor role of multiple and transparent governance must also be ensured by public authorities at various levels. The dissemination of development protocols promoting decentralisation and transparent verification, the establishment of the European observatory and the recently signed partnership are signs that we are moving in the right direction. A sense that allows the European Union to be competitive and at the same time able to use these new platforms to promote social innovation in a decentralised, secure and values-compliant manner.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and our colleagues for this fine result. Their hard work will be the basis on which we can build a framework for blockchain. But how do you build a framework for something so abstract, whose impact and capabilities we don't know, a technology that may have infinite practical applications? That is why it is important that we do not regulate the technology itself, but the applications that are being developed from it. This is the only way to prevent innovation from being restricted. That would be a great pity because the industry that is created around blockchain is already worth billions today. It's an opportunity we have to seize with both hands. Let's make Europe the "blockchain valley" of the future.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: Mr President, I have three questions for the Commission. First, the information associated with a blockchain can ultimately be traced back to individuals. That makes them vulnerable not only to hackers but also to multinationals like Google, Microsoft and Amazon. The system is inherently uncontrollable. That's in the design. How is the Commission going to control this?  Secondly, under Article 21 of the General Data Protection Regulation, people have the absolute right to be forgotten. With blockchain, the information goes into the internet and cannot be revoked. How is the Commission going to enforce the GDPR? And thirdly, the computing of blockchain takes a lot of energy. The world's two largest blockchains, Bitcoin and Ethereum, now use as much electricity as the whole of Austria. That growth is exponential. How is this compatible with the Paris climate agreement?

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to express my sincere thanks to the chairman of the STOA Committee, Eva Kaili. The new technologies are, of course, partly surprising to us, but on the other hand we are prepared to deal with them intensively. And just as letterpress has changed the world, blockchain will change the world, with all the opportunities and risks. We have a chance of trust systems being formed, and trust is something that we have lost in part on the Internet. Transparency – which algorithms are used, what about the different algorithms, what are the experts in this field worldwide, are there non-disclosure agreements here, that experts can only have their knowledge available to individual large corporations, and how can we prepare our educational landscape for this new future? I've seen in South Korea that eight-year-olds are already learning coding there. I believe that it is a challenge for us to find the right structures here. Also in vocational training, so that older, experienced employees can also survive in these technologies. And, of course, foresight technology, where we have to look at the impact this has on culture, on sport, on the economy, on the environment. I believe that these impact analyses are of particular importance. That is why the negotiations for FP9 are so important now, where we need to look at how these technologies can be re-established, for example, in private-public-partnership programmes, and how universities with small and medium-sized enterprises can promote these technologies.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, when we think of these technologies, the first thing that comes to mind are virtual currencies such as bitcoin, currencies that have been in the eye of the hurricane since its birth and especially this year after up to four hundred billion dollars of market value has recently disappeared. It's an alert. Of course, we must harness the full potential that distributed processing technologies and blockchains offer us to create fast, cheap, secure, transparent, and immutable records. We must be able to develop applications in energy networks, healthcare, education, supply chains, creative industries, the public sector. I therefore welcome the creation of the European Blockchain Observatory and the European Partnership, to which twenty-six countries have already joined. That is, joining forces, as Europe can pave the way for leadership positions in a technology that could change our lives in multiple fields. But you have to be aware of the risks in order to combat them. Bitcoin volatility is a warning. We cannot look away from momentous issues such as data protection, cybersecurity, opportunities for new avenues of fraud it offers and its environmental impact. Recent studies show that electricity consumption from the bitcoin mining network is equivalent to 1% of electricity consumption worldwide. This is not feasible. We therefore need to be aware of the opportunities and risks to maximize the former and minimize the latter.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Madam President, it is a pleasure to have the Vice—President here again. Just recently we had the #Switch Conference in Vilnius. This time 15 000 children turned up. I know you visited it once with me a few years ago. It was a conference about blockchain technology. It is here and it is here to stay. Let’s not stop it. Eva Kaili is doing a great job with this resolution, which I think is very important. I also think it is very important to educate politicians that blockchain technology or DLT does differ significantly from cryptocurrencies and bitcoin and Ethereum, and then Ethereum differs a lot from bitcoin too as it was a main means of funding a lot great projects for which Europeans got money could have never come to them before. So there is a lot of great innovation where people have been contributing from all over the world. We will see how that pans out.  Over—regulating and being too nervous is not the way to go. The European Central Bank has been quite active, and a lot of reserve banks in Europe have been quite active, warning people of the risk – and there are risks when you speculate, and the bitcoin price does fluctuate significantly – but bitcoin is here to stay. Other parts of it, like decentralisation is here to stay too, and once these technologies are decentralised we will not have much say, unfortunately. This is something that we also have to live with, because once it is decentralised it runs on its own merit. This is the current world and the current status for us all. Artificial intelligence we should not be afraid of either. We should be leading the world and we should be investing and educating ourselves to start with, our children and our great countries of Europe to lead the world forward with very liberal legislation, very open arms to create well—paid jobs for everybody, which we all need.  So I wish everyone good luck. Stay positive. This is one of the main technologies that can lead us forward. (Applause)

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
