text: – Madam President, the pace of development of new technologies is going to speed up exponentially in the future, whether the EU is on board on this development or not. It is going to be led from the Asian countries and the USA. The EU has been lagging behind because we are disintegrated Member States, not putting our efforts effectively together. So I am welcoming the Commission’s proposal and this report that sets out the importance of the EU countries and the EU as a unit working together. This means a better leveraging regulatory environment. We have to bear in mind that regulatory environments create markets. If they are badly done they prevent markets but they are precondition for the birth of markets in the future, to set the internal market. We need better research, a better venture capital approach in this area and we need a better speed up of university cooperation with entrepreneurs.  But then Madam President I would like to look on the other side of the story, and this is the risks – not because I would be against these technologies, but just because I’m in favour of these technologies. With this speeding pace of development, new kind of challenges and maybe threats are going to emerge. If we want to preserve a good technology environment, what we would need to have in the future in the EU is a special agency concentrating on new technology threats and how to combat these in a proactive manner instead of just reacting later on after a crisis has happened.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, I would first like to welcome this initiative, which has the potential to open new horizons in multiple European sectors and to thank Madam Kaili, whom I’m also collaborating with in another similar file. I am responsible for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade for the file on blockchain and forward-looking trade policy. Blockchain and DLTs have definite potential and this has been shown via recent projects around the world. I really believe that the future will be better with the help of these technologies. But at the same time we need to be pragmatic and keep in mind also the vulnerabilities and imperfections of the system like the threat of hacking, risks to cybersecurity and the environmental impact.  Consequently, we need a more environmentally friendly system and a less energy consuming one, but also one that addresses technological risks and potential security challenges. The future competitiveness and capacity for innovation of European industry could be closely related to the adoption and implementation of distributed ledger technologies. Sectors such as energy, food, health, transport and manufacturing could be significantly reshaped by these emerging technologies. What I consider crucial for these emerging promising technologies to flourish in the European Union is to adopt an innovation—friendly approach and not to rush prematurely into regulation and potentially hamper innovation. Further, to ensure companies and start—ups simplified access to, and enhance, financing within EU financial instruments. The EU needs to create an ecosystem where innovation by companies and start—ups are encouraged.  I highlight the major potential to integrate DLTs with other technologies such as the Internet of Things, artificial intelligence and quantum computing. Moreover DLTs, with enhanced cooperation between the Commission and Member States, have the potential to improve monitoring, security and verification mechanisms and to fight unlawful payments, facilitate anti—money laundering policies and detect misappropriations of assets. As regards smart contracts, it is true that they can be a key enabler of decentralised applications, but at the moment my opinion is that this technology is not mature enough to be considered legally enforceable. I close by reiterating how extremely important it is for the Member States to play an active role and strengthen the collaboration with the Commission within the recently—established European blockchain partnership which, from my perspective, is the cornerstone of the Union’s future innovation capacity and global competitiveness.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think if you asked citizens across the European Union what bitcoin and blockchain were, 99.9% would probably say: ‘what?’ They wouldn’t know. I think, for that reason, it is good that the rapporteur, Eva Kaili, is ensuring that at least we, on behalf of European citizens, are aware of what is happening and are trying to keep to up to speed with developments and to regulate sensibly. Nevertheless, the point made by my colleague, Sirpa Pietikäinen, is very valid.  I think many people, especially nowadays, feel overwhelmed by all the new technologies that have been developed. It might be a good idea for the Commission to go on some kind of information campaign to inform citizens what these technologies actually mean to them and what opportunities there are. Otherwise the negative side regarding climate and energy use and so forth will take over and it could render it difficult. So that is a suggestion.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the question put by my colleague, Mrs Kailis, on distributed ledger and blockchain technologies, I think, highlights the main problems we faced during the fourth industrial revolution. A process that is constantly progressing, as there is now a digitised European industrial area.  It is certain that the applications of the blockchain cover, as mentioned, many areas: energy networks, healthcare, the financial sector, supply chains, transport, education. They are, of course, also concerned with the public sector. I think that these issues should concern us and we should place great emphasis on cyber security, data protection and, of course, the use of this whole system, as the Commissioner has said, at the level of public services. At the same time we must pay attention to negative phenomena, such as the creation of cartels and fees with cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin.

name: Andrus ANSIP
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank Eva Kaili and all those who worked on this resolution. I would like to thank the European Parliament for the opportunity to discuss distributed ledger technologies and blockchains, and for the interesting views expressed by its Members.  The resolution to be voted on during this plenary will provide additional impetus and support to the EU’s vision for developing and promoting these technologies during the coming year. The Commission has already invested more than EUR 80 million in projects supporting the use of blockchain through Horizon 2020. The Connecting Europe Facility will support a first wave of deployment of cross-border public service use cases and engage the private sector, including cutting-edge start-ups. We are proposing more investments in the Digital Europe programme, including for European blockchain services infrastructure to ensure that Europe is at the global forefront of blockchain innovation.  The Commission is pleased that the European Parliament shares our view on the need to seize the opportunities offered by distributed ledger technology and blockchain technology, and acknowledges the importance it plays in the digital transformation of European industry and governments.  As we know, Europe is already host to more than 500 blockchain start-ups. I mentioned in my introduction that we organised the first ever ‘Blockathon’ in Europe. The aim of this ‘Blockathon’ was to better protect intellectual property rights. As we know, this is a real headache not only in the European Union, but globally. In the year 2017, 43 million European citizens bought some kind of pirated goods, and if we lost EUR 85 billion in this way, it means that we also lost 800 000 jobs in Europe. It is really good when young people would like to use this very innovative new technology to protect our jobs and intellectual property rights in the European Union.  Of course blockchain may not be the panacea that will solve all our challenges, but it is an opportunity that we cannot overlook – an opportunity for the EU to lead in new trusted business models and for public services to deliver better, more innovative services to people, in line with our legal principles and our European values.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5). The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 3 October 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – Behind the United States and China, Europe is significantly behind in modern digital technologies. While it is becoming clearer and clearer what the technological directions will be that will determine our future, it is not clear how Europe could compete with global competitors. In the areas of artificial intelligence and big data, we are already significantly behind, and unfortunately we are not able to offer a special competitive advantage that will help us to climb back to the forefront. In China, the amazing amount of data and the efficiency of central management, and in the United States, its innovative industry, provide a competitive advantage that we have nothing to show for its effectiveness.  Europe is very special and has resources that make it unique in the world. The uniformity of the internal market, its massive purchasing power and a flexible and forward-looking regulatory environment provide a basis that competitors do not have. These are precisely the conditions that are most necessary for blockchain-based technologies, so I believe that if we properly develop a framework for innovation and applicability, Europe could be at the forefront of development. I believe that this is an excellent opportunity for the Union, after the successes of the recently put in place Data Management Directive, to show once again that it can meet the challenges of the age and take the lead in a new field in the world.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Technology gives opportunity to our citizens, businesses, and to the public administration in our Member States. However, we, the members of the European Parliament, must give opportunity for technology to thrive. We must make sure that we have legal certainty for European companies. We must create European legislative framework, otherwise we risk patch-work - a fragmentation of the Digital Single Market into 28 different blocks.  Blockchain technology is still developing, yet it can deliver higher efficiencies in providing services. Perhaps the best example of a sector that embraces blockchain is the financial services, but in the “Resolution on Distributed ledger technologies and blockchains: building trust with disintermediation” we also look into how it can affect other areas and where it can have a greater impact - energy sector, health care sector, education and others.   I have been long-standing advocate for Regulation for Innovation and I see this resolution as a clear signal that Europe stand in support of blockchain and technology, and I very much welcome the commitment of the European Commission to invest up to 300 million euros by 2020.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the EU Agenda for Rural, Mountainous and Remote Areas (2018/2720(RSP)).

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity for this debate today. It gives me the opportunity and also the pleasure to discuss the needs of rural, mountainous and remote areas. As you know, one of my key priorities for future cohesion policy is a policy for all regions, with no region left behind – no rural region, no mountainous, no remote areas left behind. I have read your report and I share your concerns about rural, mountainous and remote regions, but I think we are already putting in place the right tools to help them. These regions are a very diverse group. You know very well that, for instance, the Canary Islands are very different to the north of Sweden, to give you an example. Even within one type of region – a mountainous region – there is enormous diversity. Kardzhali in Bulgaria is one of the poorest regions, whereas Heidelberg in Germany is one of the richest. Because of this diversity we need a diversity of tools, and I believe we are providing these tools in our proposals for the future.  The first tool is the territorial agenda. Integrated investments, based on the specific needs of the territory – and this includes, of course, the local actions led by local communities. The territorial agenda includes synergies within the functional areas, because, of course, rural and remote areas do not exist in a vacuum. They are linked to urban areas, while urban areas need their hinterlands. An integrated strategy balance I think this needs.  The second tool is about the integrated investments themselves, promoting accessibility and digital connectivity, energy, education, small and medium—sized enterprises, migration, services, social exclusion. We are modernising and updating these actions and I believe post-2020 they will better tackle the needs of remote, rural and mountainous regions. The third tool is about the Smart Village initiative, launched last year by Commissioners Hogan, Bulc and myself. We have now pilot actions already in place, improving rural services with ICT and making villages more sustainable, contributing to the diversification of the rural economy, which builds on the Cork 2.0 Declaration on a better life for rural areas. We are putting in place also the tools which will work for rural, mountainous and remote regions. As I mentioned, first the Territorial Agenda and integrated strategies for each region. Second, our range of investment tools which are being sharpened to tackle the needs of rural, mountainous and remote regions. Third, the Smart Village initiative, ICT at the service of rural and remote areas.  These are my first thoughts. I am looking forward to seeing your views and I know that at the end of the day we have the same goal – no region left behind.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the Commissioner is right to ask himself: are we on course? Let me note a few things. Firstly, there is a real population exodus from many rural areas. Young, vital people move to urban areas in economically stronger regions for study and work, but many do not return after that. Villages are ageing rapidly. The projections for Poland and Romania are that the population decreases by a quarter and in rural areas by half. That is why the REGI Committee, which has requested this debate, is ringing the bell from the point of view of cohesion. Secondly, Europe faces major challenges everywhere, socially, economically and technologically. Just look at the previous debate on digitisation, robotisation and the circular economy. If you don't come, you're going to be behind. We believe that far-flung areas should also be included. Thirdly, what does the REGI Committee want from you as the European Commission? In 2016, the Amsterdam Pact focused on urban policy. The role of cities has since been strengthened in many innovative actions and can no longer be seen as a spearhead in your policy and that of EU funds. It is now time to come up with a pact for rural communities. The basis for this has already been laid in the European Parliament through pilot projects launched in 2017. Now it is necessary to unite these pilot projects and to achieve one action, this time not the Amsterdam Pact but perhaps bucharest's, or better yet the Sibiu Pact under the Romanian Presidency at the beginning of 2019. This pact should not be concluded between administrators, but, as with the urban pact with the stakeholders themselves, namely rural organisations. Commissioner, it is time for action. In 2019, the preparation of the post-2020 programmes will begin in the Member States, together with the second pillar of agricultural policy, namely the European Rural Development Fund. Experience with Leader and local initiatives shows that this is more than the development of farms. Socio-economic sectors also benefit. The villages in the countryside also matter. Many villages feel forgotten. Anti-European noises are gaining a foothold. In 2017, the representatives of rural municipalities asked for a different course. The European Rural Parliament, supported by the Council of Europe and your Commission, requested a pact on 29 November 2017. I quote: "We strive for a pact of rural communities and a European rule agenda to foster our contribution and participation on European scale, parallel to the pact of Amsterdam for the cities. We are ready to contribute to a stronger relationship between citizens in our communities and the European goals". I'm shutting down. Mrs Creţu, you responded positively to this request last year. Commissioners Bulc and Hogan were also positive. The REGI Committee and the PPE Group believe that it is time for this approach. Make election year 2019 also the year of a new pact. Can I take your position?

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, Commissioner, for your introduction. As my colleague also mentioned, we in Europe have intervened, through the urban agenda, on an important part of our territory, but, I would remind you, even though it includes the majority of the population, it concerns a small amount of the territory.  As you well know, over 80% of our territory is characterized by rurality and mountain, very often the mountain is also rural, but not only. We are convinced that this part of the territory deserves non-residual attention, what is not urban and mountain is rural, but specific attention.  And why? Because it is not true that areas with a low population are destined to remain poorer and, above all, to be substantially rural areas at all times. Instead, they must be able to develop innovative policies to the full.  You mentioned the Smart Villages, and indeed we are very concerned, as a Parliament to this experience, to this experimentation, because it is quite possible that there will be innovative activities in this area, which is the majority of the territory, the one on which we also have a duty, in times of climate change, to intervene by creating a series of initiatives that avoid that precisely in these places , in particular the mountains, climate change is devastating. So research and innovation do not only concern urban areas, they also concern rural areas, mountain areas and the outermost regions of the European Union.  I was one of those who promoted the pact for cities and then the urban agenda. We now believe that the time has come to start with an agenda for rural and mountain areas and for the outermost regions, where the same objectives are set, because the objectives are common. The problem is that the way in which they are reached changes when people intervene in areas with a population that is rarely populated or with structural handicaps.  That is our objective. We want a strong signal to be given that we are really interested in rural, mountainous and outermost territories, particularly those who really care about their inhabitants, who have all the rights, such as those of the rest of the citizens of the European Union and the citizens of the big cities.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. - Madam Chairman, the EU Rural, Mountainous and Remote Areas Programme must provide answers to the most important challenges facing such areas, such as depopulation and ageing of the population, difficult mobility, economic stagnation, availability of public services and worn-out infrastructure. Although they cover 80% of the territory and 57% of the Union's population, downward economic trends show that rural, mountainous and remote areas generate 46% of gross value added today and gdp per capita is 70% of the European average.  Young people are drawn to the lights of big cities that can provide living opportunities, standards and excitement, which rural environments often cannot. But for the Union to continue to be a functioning and sustainable community in the future, life in the countryside must be preserved. There are a number of measures that can contribute to this, such as investment in infrastructure, tax relief and reduction of administrative burdens, the application of digital solutions in the development of rural areas and better exploitation of renewed energy potential. If life in the countryside is cheaper and better quality than it is now, we don't have to fear for the demographics of rural areas or their economic prosperity. Life in big cities is becoming more expensive and substandard. If we can bridge the obvious infrastructure shortcomings of much of the Union's rural area and attract young people with lower taxes and cheaper energy, these areas will quickly live up and get a new perspective.  In particular, the rural, mountainous and remote programme must address the availability and quality of public services, as well as opening markets to the private sector, which can work synergistically in raising the quality of life in the countryside. The challenges are great, and times are deducies because unfavorable demographic trends are not easy to stop. And therefore, I expect this program to be very ambitious and concrete.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – This debate, as well as the Commission's statement, as well as the European Parliament resolutions recently adopted on this topic, shows the importance of rural, mountainous and remote areas, as well as the Commission's statement, as well as the European Parliament resolutions recently adopted on this topic.  On the other hand, cohesion policy or a policy of uniform development is one of the most important European policies. But, nevertheless, it is clear from the data presented that this policy has not actually achieved its objectives. The ratio of GDP in rural, mountainous and remote areas is 70% of the European average and 123% in the city. Of course this big difference affects young people leaving these areas. At the same time, these areas are ageing and all the problems we encounter in general in society in our countries, these areas feel stronger than they do with urban areas. And these reasons, therefore, the failure of this policy and the deterioration of the situation, and even in recent years, speak of the need for a program for rural, mountainous and remote areas. It cannot be said that these cohesion policies are not successful because perhaps without them the situation would be even worse than it is now, but definitely these data show that the objectives have not been achieved.  Elementary things need to be done, better transport connectivity of these areas should be enabled, clean energy should be made available and should of course be covered by high-speed internet, and then economic activities will develop within them – some are mentioned such as rural tourism, but also any other economic activity such as energy production, such as various services, are also out of the question. And the techniques of how to do it organizationally, the steps are decentralization and subsidiarity. Specific typical simple projects should be developed for these areas due to their reduced administrative capacity. They need to be facilitated to access European funds and somewhere by direct access, as some countries, central authorities, are holding back access to these areas. And if we do, and if we link the urban and rural programme as one partner programme, then we are likely to be more successful in implementing this single European cohesion policy.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues. Rural mountain areas in the European Union make up a significant part of the territory of the European Union, home to almost fifty-seven% of the citizens of the European Union. The importance of these areas for the sustainable and sustainable territorial development of Europe is therefore undeniable. Due to their specificities, these areas and their populations face major challenges in terms of social and economic development, climate change and demographics, and the European Union's policies on these regions must therefore respect a particular concept. These regions need additional support to tackle poor accessibility, declining job opportunities, an ageing population, insufficient infrastructure and other sensitive problems. We really need to focus more on rural areas and increase synergies by coordinating the various policies, strategies and programmes of the European Union. It should be noted that the rural development funding scheme proposed by the European Commission in the new Multiannual Financial Perspective, which is separate from the funding instruments for cohesion policy, is a cause for concern. Today, much is being said about simplifying the rules on the financing of European Union funds, cutting red tape, greater synergies between The European Union's funding instruments, but the new approach proposed by the European Commission does not take into account the cohesion dimension in the rural development fund, thus preventing beneficiaries in these areas from having simplified access to different sources of funding. How much rural development – so much cohesion.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, unfortunately, we must denounce once again that the rural environment is neglected, of funds, of quality public services, of communications, of adequate policies to combat depopulation. Europe is increasingly focusing on cities, leaving the rural environment at hand.  In the face of a European urban agenda, we should strongly enhance europe's rural agenda, ensuring funds and, in particular, combating this depopulation which is a real drama.  Rural, mountainous and remote areas must be taken into account in the reform of cohesion policy, for the fixing of the population, which should be the main objective, through the provision of quality public services, the guarantee of energy and infrastructure supply or socio-economic dynamization in a sustainable manner at all levels. Specific policies on gender equality should also be implemented.  I would like to recall that last year this Parliament drew up a resolution on the role of women in rural areas which says that gender mains can be reality in all policies, also in rural development. The Commission and States are also requested to prioritise access to the women's labour market in rural areas to ensure the socio-economic development of these territories.  Public services and minimum incomes, including pensioners, should be guaranteed, including services tailored to prevent and combat violence against women.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, I am particularly - and personally - sensitive to the aid that can be provided to farmers affected by compensation for natural disability. Be aware that in France, more than 60,000 farms are included in this scheme. To quote my region of New Aquitaine alone, one third of the area of the Creuse, two thirds of that of Corrèze and half of that of the Pyrenees-Atlantics are concerned. Of course, I do not deny that the report in question focuses on an essential issue in the agricultural field, and more broadly with regard to the safeguarding of our spaces, but the farmers concerned also suffer from major handicaps which are not generated, for their part, by the natural environment, but by the European Union. After forcing member countries to dismantle public services in the most fragile territories, having destroyed the profitability of an vast majority of European farms by deregulating commodity markets, after imposing lethal free trade treaties in the midst of the agricultural crisis, the European Commission is trying to impose an unprecedented reduction in CAP aid paid to farmers. It brandishes such measures to explain that the European Union is acting in favour of the territories it ultimately ruined. It removes billions of aid with one hand and provides alms for a few additional rural development programmes. So, to look at farmers concerned with specific natural areas, yes, of course, but not without completely changing software and ending the European Commission's deadly policy.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. It is important that we once again deal with the issue of rural areas and mountain areas here in plenary. They are, in fact, of very central and fundamental importance for the further development and development of the European Union as a whole. As you have already mentioned, Commissioner, statistics say little. Statistics are an average. And if you look at rural areas in Europe, there are very, very successful rural areas. Fortunately, I come from one of these successful regions. In addition to these successful regions, there are also regions and rural areas that are lagging behind in development. It is precisely in this second group that you see people leaving, so people are going out of these areas and going to the cities. If you then look at what distinguishes the successful from the less successful ones, it is ultimately the question: is there a successful sensible rural development in the area, a real rural development policy? A real rural development policy means taking care of agriculture, taking care of tourism, also taking care of jobs in industry and crafts – because only then can the people stay on the ground – and also provide infrastructure. I am thinking of roads, of roads, but also of modern roads of our time, which are digital roads and high-performance data networks. And it needs social infrastructure, it needs hospitals, schools, kindergartens. It takes everything that people need in order to be able to live normally and so that their quality of life is roughly comparable to the quality of life in cities. That, I think, is something that people from cities often don't understand, because people from cities think that rural areas are a kind of romantic Disneyland, a space where a few backward people still live and where you just have to protect and not use it. I believe that, especially in rural areas, this link between protecting and benefiting is a very, very important one. I am also thinking, for example, of the debate we are currently having on large carnivores. You can see how some people think you only need to protect, but you don't understand that you have to use it in rural areas. And there are our policies, which are very important; for example, the common agricultural policy. I think that the proposal now on the table to reduce the second pillar of the common agricultural policy by 15% is a fatal proposal for rural areas and, above all, for more backward rural areas. This will, in fact, cause massive damage to these areas. We need a sensible European social fund, it needs structural funds, and the proposal to create smart villages is certainly the right one. Overall, I think that these rural areas are a great opportunity for Europe. But they can also become a major danger. After all, if we neglect these rural areas, we will not only lose cultural and biodiversity, we will ultimately risk natural hazards – landslides, water and so on. We should not risk that. We should look at our rural areas.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – We are talking a lot about the fair and equitable development of all European regions. We also often talk about cohesion policy. Unfortunately, however, the statistics are radically different. Every year rural settlements disappear from Europe's maps, income gaps between economic centres and other regions grow. Young people are leaving these regions in search of new opportunities. All this happens despite billions of investments and various projects and programs. The fragmentation of European policies also contributes to the fragmentation of different regions. It is time for a pan-European strategy for rural, mountainous and remote regions. European regions need to be approached in full. Only this way can a new economic model be given for those regions that have many limitations and difficulties. Of course, Member States also have a very important role to play in this process. It is high time countries like mine - Bulgaria finally started implementing strategies for mountain regions such as the Rhodopes, Strandzha, Stara Planina. These regions have huge potential, but it is high time they were taken out in front of a bracket. There must be guaranteed funding for mountain regions, for example at least 10% of cohesion funds directly distributed to mountain regions. In addition, there should be support for young people, those who produce in these regions and create jobs. It's the right way.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Among other things, the European Union is aiming at levelling the level of development and well-being of citizens. It is all about raising the living standards of the people of the Community. In its statement, the Commission singles out rural, mountainous and remote regions. I believe that the latter category should be extended to the border regions of the European Union, especially in the east, for example in Poland, such as Lublin, Podkarpatta and Podlasie. Notabene, ro also rural areas. They are characterised by a low level of technical and transport infrastructure and a quality of life of the population significantly different from the rich regions of the European Union. As a result of this situation, the inhabitants go to Western Europe and the regions depopulate. Therefore, when creating an instrument of support for remote regions, it is fair to include the border regions of the European Union as well, and I was encouraged by, among other things, today's statement by the Commissioner, in which she stated that she wanted no regions to be left out.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Life in the region has light and dark sides. From my mountaineering farm it is seven kilometers to the next place, to the nearest doctor, to the nearest shopping opportunity, to the nearest bus station or to the nearest pharmacy. And I'm still lucky. Me and my family live in a region where there is quite a lot of tourism, where this infrastructure still exists. If even this infrastructure is no longer there, which family with three children will stay in the region? Probably the very few, people move to the city. But it is not just about the infrastructure we need in the countryside. It is also a question of: how do we assess the value of rural areas? Much is said in the paper about the economic contribution, about the economic contribution that people make in the countryside. But how much do the rural regions do to make our urban population able to do what they do every day when they go out to the countryside on weekends to experience a bit of nature, to grab a bit of fresh air, to see a sunset, and to stay physically and mentally healthy? Rural areas are also an essential part of the performance of our urban population. A hint about spending money. Selling us in the countryside, minus 15%, would be a great support – I think that borders on cynicism! Nevertheless, it is also a question of what this money is used for. Will this money be used to strengthen regional economic cycles? Or is it used to bring back companies from somewhere that are building their things here? Or are farmers being supported here in direct marketing and in building up regional value-added cycles themselves? Or is it just a supermarket being put in the village by a chain? It is therefore not only a question of the amount of money, but also of the quality of investment and whether or not we really support rural areas. Unfortunately, there have been many negative examples in the past. I hope you can improve that.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Madam President, the whole of society benefits from the fresh water that flows from the mountains, its biodiversity, the landscape and even its resources, but public administrations only devote resources to maintaining and developing these areas. On the contrary, they consent to all kinds of environmental aggressions that contaminate, that damage the landscape and expel people.  Only in my country, in Galicia, quarries in courel, reforestation with inadequate species such as eucalyptus in A Fonsagrada or the works of AVE en Laza are an example of what I have just described. The desettlement of these areas is alarming. Therefore, it is urgent to adopt decided policies that foster development by promoting agro-ecological agricultural activity with strong public support for the people who live there and it is urgent to shield quality public services for all people. I therefore demand, Commissioner, that the resolution adopted in this Parliament on cohesion policy in May 2016 apply.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, without question, today the European Union faces many challenges, whether we are talking about the unequal effects of the urban and rural development process, generated in particular by the difference in living standards between the two areas, the difference in digitalisation and automation, whether we are talking about population movements in mountainous or remote rural areas , otherwise vulnerable areas and due to the continued loss of biodiversity and the impact of climate change.  Access infrastructure, transport, public health and education are essential elements for any community, however, and their lack in rural mountain communities further aggravates the irreversible process of depopulation. I therefore believe that investment in the provision of these services must be a priority for any public authority.  At the same time, the natural potential of mountainous or low-access rural areas is an invaluable added value. Encouraging models of the development of local economies by exploiting their natural resources or supporting short food chains would contribute significantly to the economic development of these communities. I stress that the new proposal of the common agricultural policy places particular emphasis on attracting young people to agriculture and developing smart villages models. However, we must bear in mind that young people are only attracted to the countryside if they have at least access to high-speed internet networks and adequate digital services to enable them to implement innovative projects, and here the role of cohesion policies is a decisive one and, I might say, even a decisive one. Local communities' initiatives to engage in local development projects, we must recognise that they have achieved remarkable results, the partnerships of local authorities with the private environment, civil society, for the establishment of local action groups have led to the development of integrated strategies for responsible community development.  The LEADER Rural Programme has also proven to be a highly effective tool for community development. However, I believe that much more could be done, so I appreciate that local authorities must be actively involved in increasing the attractiveness of these areas and the ability to integrate newcomers, taking advantage of the tools made available to them, encouraging exchanges of experience and implementing as many actions as possible to attract new inhabitants. Last but not least, the expertise capacity of local action groups must be supported with more comprehensive funding. I also appreciate that there is a much more substantial synergy between cohesion funds and those in the common agricultural policy, namely those in Pillar II. I believe that today this synergy is under-exploited, thus requiring increased efforts by the authorities in this regard.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, it has important ramifications when it comes to the situation of women in rural areas, such as Cumbria in my northwest England constituency. Indeed, the theme of this year’s UN Conference on the Status of Women was precisely focused on this topic, as the situation of women in rural areas requires specific policy responses at all levels. Our priority must be to uphold the rights of women, girls and LGBTIQ+ people in rural areas. Their role in crucial sectors, such as the fight against climate change, is extremely important. In many cases they are also at the forefront of economic and social innovation, yet their specific situation is not taken into account by many policy makers. In this respect, I’m proud of the 2014 European Parliament report on the Green Employment Initiative, which I worked on from a FEMM Committee perspective. We ignore the contribution and wisdom of 21st century rural women at our peril. Those who live and work in rural, mountainous and remote areas are often the problem solvers and the change makers, but they need equal access to resources, including the internet and finance.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, rural, mountain and remote areas must be supported by the European Union both with cohesion policy funds and with funds for the common agricultural policy.  Of course, specific factors must be taken into account, which will help to provide a functional definition of what the 'mountain region' means. Because we know that there are areas where the great limitation of land use due to slope, terrain and altitude needs to be taken into account. Productivity needs to be taken into account. Difficult weather conditions need to be taken into account. At the same time, there must be a solution to the issue of compensatory compensation given to Greece, because since 2016 it has been reduced by 50%. In fact, the procedure applied by the Greek Government to the demarcation of areas with natural restrictions leads to a reduction in the compensatory allowance, which is contrary to what the European Union wants. Let us also take into account the cost of production, the expensive agricultural oil that exists in Greece, the lack of agricultural credits, the lack of training and education, and above all the problem with the Greekisation of agricultural products and the Greekisation of livestock products, an issue on which both the European Union and of course the Greek Government must take action. Specific interventions are therefore needed to support mountain areas, to support our farmers, to support our farmers.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: Madam President, I am from the Pyrenees, where I still live. I want to say this because for me and many, among them young people, the mountain is a choice of life. But today, there are more and more gender gaps in employment and access to care, so-called positive mobility, digital mobility, and, increasingly, school, recreation or culture. I do not think this is inevitable, but it is, in the end, the price to be paid for years of austerity policies, competition of territories, deep cuts in public service budgets - as evidenced, or rather as evidenced by, the future multi-year financial framework for cohesion or CAP. In my opinion, it is now a question of changing the programme, but above all of changing the logic so that the mountainous and isolated rural areas are not relegation territories and their populations are sub-citizens. The European Union must make it a priority - in my region, we are talking about a mountain exception: priority in its cohesion policy in terms of resources, priority in terms of support for local employment and, as my colleagues have said, priority in terms of equal rights - and I am thinking in particular of women.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to welcome the holding of this debate because I do not think that this discussion could be more timely, just at a time when we are discussing the legislative framework of the next multiannual financial framework and its policy instruments. Just this weekend, at a conference in Portugal in which I participated in a more interior area and with the same problems described here, what the fellow citizens most interested in was how the European Union will be able to adapt its cohesion policy to the territorial, effective and permanent development of the territories we are talking about here today.  The diagnosis is made in all its aspects and is by us well known. Moreover, this diagnosis is well summarised in the resolution. Now we need to act and do so as a union of peoples and States, but also through our Member States, regions, local authorities or even with the help of international partners, as has happened recently using the World Bank's technical assistance in pilot projects to help the less developed regions of the European Union. I have said this - I would like to repeat this - on the road to intra- and extra-regional convergence, both within and outside borders, both the urban agenda and support for these territories, should always be the two sides of the same currency, i.e. territorial development objectives supported by smart, sustainable growth strategies for our cities and especially for medium-sized ones , for our regions, sub-regions and municipalities, should always take into account the specificities of the most central urban reality, the surrounding urban network and the most remote rural territories and further away from these same centers. This seems obvious to me.  We can also start from the most remote, rural or mountain areas with a low urban or demographic density in order to articulate or design specific policies for the development of these territories, involving the most remote urban centers, but with service or infrastructure that will inevitably be needed to implement functional and successful strategies. That is why this agenda must gain greater institutional visibility and also greater political visibility and the example set by the initiative for the most depressed regions, the so-called Lagging Regions Initiative, but now also called the Catching-Up Regions Initiative - indeed a new name that I consider happier - could be an important lever for this important agenda that needs to be implemented on the ground and this is all for the sake of the equitable development of all our regions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Madam President. I welcome today's debate, because 57% of the Union's population lives in remote regions, and cities depend mainly on the countryside for land use, food production or raw materials. Positive examples of access to the least developed regions in our countries already exist. We need to pay more attention to them. In order to have a consistent European Union agenda for rural, mountainous and remote regions, it is essential that it be coordinated with strategies for lagging and peripheral regions. In this respect, the Commission can be inspired in the cohesion countries that have successfully put such strategies into practice. As an example, I give my country Slovakia. We can describe in the action plans the main causes of their unfavourable condition. These are often similar factors: low labour qualifications, non-use of local resources, lack of cooperation at local level, etc. I believe that the Commission should take all this into account.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: – Hello, Honourable Commissioner. I am very pleased that today we are talking about an agenda for areas from rural areas, mountain areas and remote areas, and as has already been said today, today is the right time for this, because we have a period of new financial perspective ahead of us, and much will depend on what we do in the new financial perspective. 80% of the territory, 57% of the population lives in these areas, we know that GDP is much lower and the key consequence of all this is the exodus of people from these areas, and this must be stopped in any way. Demographers' predictions that as many as 80% of Europeans will live in metropolitan regions in 2050 must not be realised. As you mentioned, the campaign for smart villages, my colleague Tibor Šani, is leading an activity here in Parliament, which is also run by three Commissioners in the Commission area, and in this activity we want, above all, to present what needs to be done. On the one hand, provide quality jobs and, on the other hand, quality living conditions.  As it is for both young people and for the elderly, that is, for all generations, and without the help of cohesion funds, the funds from the rural development programme will be virtually impossible to achieve. Something that in a big city can be a business case, a business model, in the countryside needs public assistance, especially in the beginning. In this activity, we are talking about the basic area of agriculture, which must certainly be complemented by other things, such as tourism, social, education, education, the retail economy, because today the countryside is much more than just a basic agricultural activity.  Synergies between all funds, a coordinated agenda in this area are the guarantor of the need for the whole of Europe to be inhabited after the coming decades and that we can have cohesiveness in our society.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the Commissioner for his contribution to this debate. What we are discussing today is becoming increasingly important for cohesion policies and for the Union itself. European GDP per head in non-urban areas is 70% of the Union average, while the inhabitants of some urban areas have a GDP per head of 123% of the average. The disparity and the gap are clear to everyone, and that is why the Commission's support for Parliament's call for an agenda for rural, mountain and peripheral areas can no longer be deferred.  These choices are obligatory if we really want to respond to those citizens who live in areas of important economic impact, but perhaps are not even reached by the Internet, and I say this as a representative of an island that is the southern periphery of Europe and which lives on the dual condition of insularity and having a rural area of important proportions, and then a strategic framework for the sustainable development of these areas is urgently required. , and for the verification of everything that is in the union's own objectives.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – One of the european Union's main challenges is the phenomenon of unequal territorial development, which is a key issue for the population retention power of rural areas and thus, in fact, for the future of these regions. Today, the development poles are clearly the big cities that want to compete globally with other developed centres around the world.  In the meantime, however, we must pay particular attention to rural areas, which serve as residences for a wide range of society, and these citizens have the same expectations for development as their counterparts in the big city.  In many Member States, a development policy that exacerbates inequalities is a problem, allowing rural areas to fall behind without outliers in large cities. We need a regional development policy that pays particular attention to direct investment in rural areas and balances existing development differences according to local needs.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, dealing with these areas, which the Lisbon Treaty put together in an article, is indeed a duty.  I will talk specifically about mountain areas. In the eyes of a number of our fellow citizens - the urban citizens - the mountain is a snowfield, it is a tourist area, but the truth of the mountain, for those who live there, is very different.  Many have mentioned here, since earlier, the aging of the population. I would like to emphasise the extra cost that is driven by the mere fact of altitude. Building a building, building equipment, means that, because of the cold and snow, there are significant extra costs, and it is through future investments in economic matters that we will guarantee the future of mountain areas. It is not a question of providing any aid to the operation, it is a question of avoiding a new divide in relation to the mountain territories that we need. We need them to be alive and well-maintained because they preserve the environment and because they protect the areas below.  Without a manicured mountain, life will also be impossible down there, in the valleys.

name: Florent MARCELLESI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, in Spain between Teruel and Cuenca there is less population density than in Lapland. This is the hidden face of today's industrial and urban development. The field, more machined, unattended and belittled than ever before, is emptied. Lose wealth, employment, diversity and life. In the face of this, we need an ambitious European strategy, with a new approach where demographic change and ecological transition play a central role. And we also need a proper territorial analysis to know the challenges they know, these rural, mountainous and remote areas suffer. It is clear to me that the rural world can be the spearhead of an ecological and fair transition, employment-intensive and low-carbon, with fewer industrial agriculture and macro-farming and more organic, local and extensive agriculture, with less coal and more renewable energy, with fewer corporate monocultures and more economic diversification. In February I sent you some proposals to combat depopulation, and I hope you will take them into account.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, it must be said that we are talking about an area that is around 80% of the territory of the European Union, so this is a great potential that we have in this territory, for example in the Czech Republic it is about 73% of the territory that we count among agricultural, mountainous or remote areas. This is a potential especially in agriculture, agricultural business, quality environment, tourism. In short, the cultural and natural wealth of these areas is considerable and, as has already been said here, it must be protected, but also cared for and made possible by life, business development, employment. The only way we can support this is by building infrastructure, by ensuring investment, transport, services and, today, the Internet. The clear agenda that the European Union has is a cohesion policy and also an instrument of the common agricultural policy.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Rural, mountainous and remote areas make up the majority of the Territory of the European Union and are inhabited by more than half of its inhabitants. Unfortunately, however, they are still in an unprepared position – their GDP is systematically lower than in urban areas. They face the problem of depopulation and outflow of young people, they have even worse access to the internet. There is therefore no doubt that these regions require us to provide special support and care.  I believe that, among other things, an excellent tool to provide such support is the Interreg programme, which, in more than twenty-five years of its existence, has already demonstrated its effectiveness in tackling trans-regional challenges, effectively finding added value in the differences between areas. I therefore believe that, during the negotiations on the new Multiannual Financial Framework, this instrument should be given a sufficiently high budget so that it can continue to provide effective support to rural, mountainous and remote areas.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Madam President, the key to vibrant rural, mountainous and remote areas is to make sure people live there. People will live there if they have income and services and feel they have a future. My concern, in my own country for example, is that there is a huge uncertainty, particularly among beef farmers, because of the potential impact of Brexit, but also because of the low incomes that they are earning and a real fear that their firms will not be taken over by young people, despite our efforts in agriculture policy to make sure that we do have incentives for young people to take over their farms. I welcome this debate, because I hope it will bring coordination between policies that are aimed at these regions that we want to serve, but the crisis at farm level is deep and farmers are beginning to question whether their work is valued. This is why, this evening in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI), we voted through a report to tackle unfair trading practices in the food supply chain. It’s a first step towards transparency and to try and get better returns back to farm level and back to the rural regions.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I have been in charge of a small municipality for eight years, so I know quite a lot about the problems we are talking about here. Indeed, we are seeing a very unequal approach in the development of regions, with 80% of the European population living in cities by 2024. I do not want this development, on the other hand, I am not so optimistic that we can stop it completely. This means: What concrete measures should we take to ensure that these developments do not occur in Europe? It is important that these mountain and rural areas have sufficient infrastructure, whether it is roadside, whether it is, of course, high-speed internet. The Czech Government is failing quite a lot on this issue. That's really bad. Amenities: there must be affordable services, schools, health care. Undoubtedly, there must be social services. And we should know that we need to translate all these priorities into our long-standing financial framework, we are talking not only about smart cities, but also about smart villages.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support I apologize for going to another debate during the debate. I would just like to add to this debate that I have been a raporter of the Roma strategy before, and in the last two years, the Commissioner has had such good reports from here in Parliament. In the past, there was also the microregion report, but if you look only at the discrimination part: a fellow Socialist MEMBER produced a report that showed that people in the poorest or most secluded settlements are more discriminated against. It is 1999 that my fellow Member spoke of the decline or termination of service in post-communist times, for example in Eastern Europe.  And that perhaps, indeed, as Mr van Nistelrooij said, the following year such a Bucharest pact would, in fact, be such an anti-poverty pan-European strategy, these five areas that you have examined in recent years and parliament has given you reports and proposals on them, in such a Pan-European poverty strategy, in the most secluded regions – perhaps look at the crisis map that we produced in 2011.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you once again for this debate tonight. It has been very interesting for me. I have heard many different opinions and interventions, but with one common feature: our passion for the development of rural, mountainous and remote areas. You know very well that two years ago we were all desperate about Brexit, about the gap left by the second largest donor. We thought about the idea of having this cohesion policy just for the less—developed regions and it was my battle to defend this policy as a policy for all regions. As I said in the beginning, my motto has always been ‘No region left behind’.  I share a lot of your views. Two weeks ago, I went to eastern Croatia. We made a plan for construction after the war. Last week I was in the Mezzogiorno, the less-developed region of Italy. This week I will be in Greece. So I know very well all these tragedies. I see them everywhere, especially in the old villages with ageing populations and people living in sparsely populated areas. I know very well that young people are leaving, in my own family also. This is also one side of the coin, the liberty we achieved in 1989 – to have the right to move and the right to choose where to work and where to live. But I think it is our duty at European level, and also at the national level, to do whatever it takes to encourage people to remain in their villages.  Your work is a very useful input for me and for us to discuss the post—2020 Territorial Agenda. You know that our proposal is now in your hands, in the hands of the European Parliament and the Council as co—legislators, and I am looking forward to the start of the trilogue. My wish, and I think it’s very important for all of us, for all the countries, for all the regions, is to have an agreement during the Romanian Presidency, because it is very important to start implementing the programmes from day one of the programming period, from 1 January 2021. We have had a lot of delays, and we have to learn from the lessons of the past, as the main reason for the delays we have now is the late adoption of the legislation for 2014—2020.  I mentioned some of the tools. I think we have to have synergies between rural development, the ERDF and other instruments, an integrated approach to local development, the territorial tools of cohesion policy and, as I said, the Smart Villages initiative, which is very important to me and Commissioner Hogan. We know very well that we cannot encourage young people in the 21st century to go where there is no broadband, where we don’t have water and where we don’t have electricity, so it’s very important to bridge this gap. We should also remember diversity. Some of you come from very rich rural areas, some of you live in very poor rural areas, so it is obvious that one size does not fit all, and we need a diversity of tools. I don’t think we should talk about money because it is not about money. The fact that we don’t have an agenda for rural, mountainous and remote areas does not mean that we don’t care about these areas. You know very well that in 2016 we had this core declaration to mainstream rural development and the new action for Smart Villages in 2017, which was a joint initiative by Commissioners Hogan, Bulc and I to develop a long—term vision and an integrated strategy for rural areas. Also under cohesion policy there is the possibility to modulate the EU core financing rate to take into account areas with natural or demographic handicaps such as mountains and, of course, the northern sparsely populated areas, which already benefit from higher aid intensity.  However, I very much encourage you to talk with your governments because we have national programmes and regional programmes, and it is up to the governments how much they will invest in the regions. In our Regulation that you have on the table, for 2014-2020, 75% of the money is going to the less-developed regions, and for 2021-2027, 80% – more than today – will go to less-developed regions. As I have stressed already, it’s very important to fighting poverty and I think it was right to raise this point, because we aren’t tackling migrants or nationalities, we are tackling human beings and their lives, and it is very important to have a special strategy for these vulnerable people and for fighting poverty. Ms Ward and Ms Vallina raised an issue that is very close to my heart, that of gender equality. This is not only an issue only for rural areas. I have launched a campaign for more women in public administration in general, but especially in local administration, because everywhere it’s a tragedy. You don’t see women running to be mayors of villages or local councillors, so I think it’s very important to raise awareness and to encourage women to run for local administration. The idea from Mr van Nistelrooij is a very beautiful idea. I started my mandate with the adoption of the urban agenda under the Dutch Presidency and I have to pay tribute once again to the Mayor of Amsterdam, Mr van der Laan, for his passion to have this urban agenda in place. It will be very emotional and beautiful if we end our mandate with a pact for rural areas during the Romanian Presidency. Let’s work together to put all our ideas in place, and see how we can adapt to all the diversity that we have in these areas. Thank you once again. It has been, as always, a pleasure to be with you tonight.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I have received, in accordance with Article 123, paragraph 2, a motion for a resolution to close this debate. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, October 3, 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. – We know that there are very large differences in development between regions in the European Union, especially between west-east and north-south. This is especially true for rural, rural and mountainous regions. These areas are still very high in terms of unemployment and are increasingly disconnected from the more developed urban parts of the Union in terms of GDP per capita. A quarter of rural and mountain households do not have broadband internet access. I think this is unacceptable in the 21st century. What is particularly worrying is the demographic challenges in rural and mountainous areas. The average age of the population, the proportion of over-65s and the increasing exodus of young people are leading to depopulation of these areas. If we add that 80% of the EU's territory is not an urban region, then we see how challenging this is and not a marginal issue. The European Commission must come up with a specific strategy to help non-urban regions catch up. Programmes should be offered that take into account the specificities of these areas and the needs of the people living there. There is no time for procrastination, and action must be taken as soon as possible, which is why this motion for a resolution is important.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the Regulation).

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, as was also pointed out in the previous debate, the common agricultural policy and cohesion policy are the cornerstones of the European Union. Solidarity, smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, the removal of social disparities would not be possible without the two policies being strongly financed and supported by facts and not by words.  The expected cuts in these policies are a consequence of Brexit. Moreover, they are also generated by the inability of some Member States to understand the need to contribute to the European Union budget at a level that enables it to face new challenges, to ensure the safety and security of the citizen, a sustainable pact and an effective cohesion policy. Without financial resources, farmers will not be able to provide cheap and quality food, many of whom will be sentenced to bankruptcy. At the same time, the gaps between the regions of the European Union will widen significantly and the depopulation of certain areas would be massive.  Therefore, countries such as Austria or the Netherlands, and beyond, must understand that the strong European Union cannot exist without substantial funding.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, on 12 August, my former Reading Borough Council Park ward colleague, Christine Borgars, who had given great service to the community, died after a long illness. In April, when Christine and I last met, she said to me that if she lived in a civilised country, she could choose to end her own life when it became intolerable because it was, after all, her life. As her time approached, she expressed the same view. Christine and many others have expressed this view to me over the years and, on their behalf, I raise this issue again in this House. Every day, terminally ill people face suffering that they would choose to end, but are denied the right to die with dignity by most Member States. The right to life is recognised as a human right. To live according to one’s own beliefs is recognised as a human right. It is high time that the right to choose to die with dignity was recognised as a fundamental human right of every European.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: – The Madam Chairman, Bosnia and Herzegovina, is expected to have a general election on October 7th. Since they are maintained according to the existing election law, there is again a risk of voting Croats as a constituent people who, unfortunately, in such a BiH do not have the right to choose their own political representatives, but are elected by more numerous Bosniaks. It is shameful that in the middle of Europe electoral engineering can stretch an entire nation, and it is especially disturbing that this is happening in Bosnia and Herzegovina, a state of very delicate structure and damaged interethnic relations.  Sarajevo by obstructing the change in electoral law and wanting to keep all voices that do not agree to a unitary state under Bosniak domination secret shows that it is not up to solving the political crisis. The European Parliament adopted resolutions on BiH warning of unitaristic and separatist dangers. If we want a stable BiH, we should support a proper election law and sustainable constitutional regulation. This isn't it now.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Madam President, I would like to contribute this minute to avoiding tragedies such as those that cost Irune Fautsman' life, Idurre, Laura, Jesus..., the dozens of people who die each year on level in the Spanish State. The last, a minor, on September 11, in Gaintxurizketa.  Some of these infrastructures are black spots that expect solutions. In order to encourage them, I call for investigations into these claims to be carried out by independent authorities, as required by European law for serious accidents, because some of the ones I have supervised are so partial and deficient that they encourage suspicion. They also involve a second victimization for the families of the deceased. And they make it difficult to map identify and prioritize urgent works to avoid the most obvious risks.  In addition, available visual control and automatic braking technologies should be applied to detect and avoid obstacles on the track. We can only talk about "accidents" when we have taken all possible measures to prevent them.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: – Madam President, I would like to talk about a problem that worries many households: the bill of light. Eurostat says Spain has the most expensive light in Europe. Galicia is even more expensive. The figures indicate that we are European consumers with the most expensive light according to market price. The price shall be fixed on the basis of the hourly allocation of electricity on the market for energy suppliers. Ten years of increases in which the bill increased by 55%. As expensive as in Germany, with the difference that the level of income is lower.  15% of consumers cannot meet their household needs such as turning on the light, washing themselves with hot water or putting on heating because part of their income is paying for electricity. This is energy poverty, cold and a reduction in quality of life.  Energy is a basic common good in which there is a lot of business and it should be forbidden to cut the light. We must promote in Europe free access to a basic common good as the light for the most deprived homes. In the face of gold-priced electricity and electricity cuts, we will continue to fight for a fair electricity tariff at fair prices.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Madam President, I want to denounce here and today the lack of plurality, manipulation and control that the Galician Government has over Galician radio and public television. This prompted workers and company workers to mobilize. There are already nineteen journeys of black viernes. They call for an end to control by the Galician Government of public radio and television, to respect the impartiality and plurality that all the media must have and to respect the labour rights of workers and workers.  The European Commission and this Parliament must urgently intervene in order for the Galician Government to put an end to years of control and manipulation that have converted Galician radio and television into the government and people's party's communications office.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Madam President, however people voted in the 2016 referendum, they’re entitled to know what’s happening, but a withdrawal agreement is still nowhere near being agreed. There never was going to be the mythical good deal offered by the European Union. It has absolutely no incentive to offer one.  Some say that Ms May is totally incompetent, but maybe she knows exactly what she’s doing. Ms May is a remainer who does not want to leave. She leads a political class that does not want to leave. At the last minute she will pull a withdrawal agreement from the hat whereby we leave in name, but not in reality, and it will be trumpeted as a great diplomatic triumph. Britain will have been betrayed. Brexit will have been betrayed. The real fight to free Britain from the European Union will then begin in earnest, and it will be led by the UK Independence Party.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: On 28 September, Indonesia was hit by a tsunami that killed more than 1,200 people. Entire cities were destroyed.  Faced with the scale of the disaster, international solidarity must be organized. European states such as France have already offered their help. I am pleased that the European Union has in turn intervened by providing eur 1.5 million in humanitarian aid. The European Parliament itself has shown its compassion for the victims by observing a minute's silence.  This event must make us aware of two things. The first is that the European Union will only survive if it transforms itself into a Europe of nations with a focus on respect for states and peoples, rather than the jungle of ultraliberal globalism. The second is that climate disasters comparable to the one that just hit Indonesia will multiply.  In addition to humanitarian considerations, it is in Europe's interest to help the States that will be victims of it in order to avoid further migratory, climatic submersion.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I just want to respond that today in the daily news you can see that the Commission has already taken the decision to release EUR 1.5 million for the victims of the Indonesian earthquake. You can see this in today’s daily news.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I would like to draw attention to the Report of the Ombudsman of the Union, which has just been published and which points to the disastrous state of the rule of law in the European Union. Points out that the post of Secretary-General has been filled in violation of all procedures. We knew this before. The report clearly confirms this, and there is a sad confirmation that none of the Commissioners opposed it, especially since we know that this is Mr Selmayr, who was already known for his macatric handling at the border of the law. And what? And no one somehow hair from the head for this reason does not fall, even though it was violated right. Mr Selmayr remains in office, while the Union instructs other countries such as Poland on the rule of law and the legality of judicial respect. Well, this is a very bad prognosticator.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, yesterday was September 30th and we in the Czech Republic commemorated the 80th anniversary of the great shock, humiliation and betrayal of its allies in the Young Czechoslovak Republic. It was decided on us and without us back then in Munich. Messrs Chamberlain, Daladier and Mussolini believed Hitler that the concession would prevent war. And he didn't.  Today we can commemorate this sad date so that we know that peace and freedom have been redeemed by millions of victims. We need to remind the younger generation of this date to understand why we are defending the European Union so much as a community where it is not decided on us and without us. It's important not to forget.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, I want to deal this evening with the issue of chlordecon, the pesticide that was used to eliminate the banana weevil and was recognised as carcinogenic in 1979 by the WHO, but used in the French West Indies until 1993. It is certainly a state scandal for France, but it has become a real global problem, as it is true that, like glyphosate or asbestos, this product remains present in the soil and in the water. It also remains present in fish, crustaceans, shellfish and other seafood products. It has become a global problem because it has been used in South America, in addition to the French West Indies, but also in Africa, and we are importing here in Europe many of these products that still contain this type of molecules. There is an urgent need to review EU legislation to lower the maximum thresholds for pesticide residues in the food we eat. I am speaking here to the European Commission to do so as a matter of urgency, because there is an urgent need for the health of the 500 million Europeans.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, the troika policies implemented for eight years in Greece have created a vast social graveyard, with armies of unemployed and millions of poor people. Pensioners lost 40% of their pension. Already 1,157,000 pensioners, i.e. a quarter of them, live on pensions of less than EUR 500 gross, while the plundering of 80,000 widow's pensions continues. And as if that were not enough, lenders are demanding a further pension reduction from 1 January 2019.  The SYRIZA-ANEL government, instead of repealing the law on new pension cuts, continues to make a trade with pensioners. So today he tabled in the House a draft state budget with two scenarios: with cuts and without pension cuts. And as a young Pontius Pilate, the government refers to the question of whether or not to reduce pensions in the Eurogroup on 3 December. Greek pensioners send a message to the government: "Hands off pensions! That's enough!"

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: – Mr President, the minimum wage in Portugal is one of the lowest in the European Union, a reality that is not disconnected from the impositions of the troika and right-wing politics, which has imposed the loss of income and the increase in poverty, and from the low-wage policies that the European Union promotes.  If the minimum wage is now set at 580 euros this is inseparable from the struggle of Portuguese workers and the rejection of right-wing policies. But besides being insufficient, its expression in the wage bill has been increasing and has already been paid by a quarter of workers in Portugal.
