Low wages remain the predominant political option, constituting one of the causes of huge and glaring social inequalities, a reality that requires raising the minimum wage to 650 euros as early as January, a necessary contribution to the replacement of lost purchasing power framed in policies of general wage increase, whether in the public or in the private.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support The democratic constitutional referendum scheduled for 6-7 December, which sets the basis for the family in a marriage of free will between a man and a woman, stirs angry anger in Romania. In the face of left-wing, globalist attacks on human and minority rights, the initiators stand up for normality. The initiative, which is also supported by churches, is not against someone or something, but rather to protect the traditional Christian marriage and family model. In Europe, which has been swayed by its national and religious identity, we must also confront the multifaceted crisis of marriage and family, and protect our natural biological identity against the gender view of the Istanbul Convention!

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, from 1 January 2019, Romania will exercise the rotating presidency of the European Union. Thus, under the presidency of Romania will be voted on the budget of the European Union for the period 2021-2027.  I note and appreciate that cohesion policy is for the first time in the history of the European Union the portfolio with the highest amount allocated in the future budget, i.e. EUR 373 billion, and Romania, Bulgaria and Greece have foreseen an increase of more than 10% in the cohesion funds allocated to the current amounts. It is an important signal to the citizens of the countries that later joined and where Europe's so-called multi-speed plan was not very well received.  In this way, I welcome the European Commission's initiative, which gives a positive signal: that despite all the discussions in recent years on the future of Europe, we are determined to live and develop together, with as little differences as possible between Member States. Europe together is and must remain our objective.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In many of the documents being voted on in our House and in the current preparations, there are provisions on decarbonisation, and that is total. Their authors cite the Paris Agreement. It should therefore be recalled that it provides for voluntary use, its own raw materials policy and its own path to the objective of reducing CO2 emissions for the signatory countries. The Paris Agreement cannot therefore amount to a complete move away from coal, because we can reduce carbon emissions, inter alia, by using the latest technologies in the construction of new energy blocks. In transport, for example, we can increase the share of hydrogen as an alternative fuel, which will also lead to the So-called ambitious climate targets of the European Union. Hydrogen can be obtained, among other things, by carbon gasification. In Poland, for example, one million tonnes of hydrogen are already produced from other raw materials per year, and according to specialists, this is enough to feed around five million cars a year.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: Madam President, it has been a year since the Free Trade Treaty between Canada and the European Union came into force. What do we see? On our plates is the arrival of GMO rapeseed, transgenic salmon, cereals produced with atrazine, a herbicide banned in Europe because it is considered carcinogenic, but allowed in Canada like 41 other pesticides.  Is the Commission moved by this? No, she persists and signs. This summer, it entered into a new large-scale trade agreement with Japan. A few days ago, it decided to significantly increase U.S. beef import quotas, in a context of reduced CAP budgets and farmers' employment. Opacity of negotiations, social and ecological denial, total lack of food democracy, exceptional justice for multinationals... We really need to hear people's opposition to free trade.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would like to comment on a subject that is extremely important to me, and that is the weakening of cohesion policy, particularly in relation to the preparation of the new Multiannual Financial Framework. This is a really sensitive issue, and, except that cohesion policy is generally weakened by the reduction of the budgetary share, new conditions are to come to limit or make the use of this money to eliminate and close the regional disparities. Conditions are therefore to come which are indeed politically sensitive, I must mention the reception of refugees.  I would like to say that I agree with some of the conditions, but for some, such as the one already mentioned, I consider this aspect to be a journey to hell. If we want to maintain the role of cohesion policy as a very dominant instrument from those European policies, then it is not possible to accept conditions that make the use of these funds subject to a highly political issue, I think that does not really belong in the new framework and I would very much like us to be able to change that together.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: – Madam President, the hearing of the Romanian Prime Minister in the European Parliament was requested, considering that the rule of law was violated in Romania as a result of the intervention of the gendarmerie at the last protest in Bucharest, which, attention, was unauthorised and where some of the protesters forced their way into the Government building. Two similar events took place this weekend: on Friday, 28 September, in Brussels, Belgium, protesters forced their way into Parliament and attacked law enforcement, fighting back with tear gas, batons and water cannons, and the second, on Saturday, 29 September, in Barcelona, Spain, law enforcement using batons to reassure protesters disrupting an authorised demonstration. However, no one will ask for the hearing of the prime ministers of the two countries in the European Parliament simply because such actions to restore public order using batons, tear gas and water cannons are legal under European and national law. Stop, Madam President and ladies and gentlemen, the application of the double standard in the European Union: what is legal in Belgium and Spain is also legal in Romania. I no longer want double language based solely on the name of the state in question.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Madam President, on Wednesday, a major rally will take place in Dublin to highlight the emergency housing crisis. Ten years after the banking crash in Ireland, the EU poster child of economic recovery is nothing more than a facade. Tonight at least 9527 people, of which 3700 are children, are homeless in Ireland. Children ashamed to tell their school friends that they have no home; children doing their homework in the toilet because there’s nowhere else quiet to go; eating junk food because their parents have nowhere to cook.  A lack of security of tenure means thousands more are living in terror that they will be next to join the homeless numbers, and all the while the Irish government pays exorbitant subsidies to the private rental sector in place of building public housing. Now, as a final insult, they want to transfer public lands to private developers to build houses that low and middle income families will never afford. This human tragedy will leave a legacy for years to come, and it is brought to you courtesy of the so-called stable politics of Fine Gael and their pals in the EPP.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to draw your attention to the case of the common man. This is the case of Jiri Sagan, who was recently convicted in France for allegedly smuggling 15 Iraqis. A man who's been driving a truck for 15 years who's never had a problem with the police in his life. He is an up-to-life citizen of the Czech Republic living in Spain, where he lives with his wife, who is seriously ill.  French authorities have given him 18 months in prison for allegedly smuggling people. Those people confirmed they got in his truck without him knowing. Is this the rule of law? This is the European Union Commissioner, for whom I am to fight and to explain to the people? Do 18 months really feel fair and justifiable to a man who has done nothing? I ask you to look into this matter within the Commission and help Emmanuel Macron understand what law and justice is.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, in Liverpool, which was the 2010 European Capital of Culture, a poignant piece of artwork has been consistently damaged by racist vandals this summer. The artwork lists the names of 34 361 migrants who have died trying to reach safety in Europe. It stood as a reminder of the horrifying risks that people are forced to undertake in order to seek safety and a sustainable life. This memorial was desecrated by right-wing thugs. Since the referendum in June 2016, there has been a 57% increase in reports of hate crime in the UK. In Greater Manchester, in my constituency, a third of people recently surveyed have reported being the victims of hateful abuse based on their ethnicity. Last week, however, at the Fundamental Rights Forum in Vienna, I met a successful young business student. He was one of the lucky ones: a Syrian refugee who did not drown as he crossed the Mediterranean. He is building a new life with the support of NGOs and the community which has welcomed him.

name: Răzvan POPA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I draw attention to a serious fact: the tendency of some Members of the European Parliament to make Romania an election campaign target, a means to a personal political purpose, linked to future European elections, is unacceptable. Romania is a stable country, where laws are respected and institutions operate. Romania is a country with a political class and citizens deeply attached to European values and the European project. They're indisputable realities. That is why I am addressing my colleagues in Romania, from all political groups, not to accept the denigration of their country, not to participate in such actions that can affect the country's image and credibility at european level and to react to unfair attacks on Romania. Stop persecuting Romania, because this only serves the enemies of the European project who want to see the European Union divided!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr. Popa, could you put on your headphones, please? I would just like to point out that the rule would be that, in a plenary debate on a situation, one-minute speeches do not address this subject. I would point that out to you, I have let you speak, but as a general rule, that is not the way to proceed.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Dear sitting leader! Commissioners, colleagues, i would like to thank the Rapporteur, Mr Sánchez- There's not much of him here. In a small minority, we are here, as always in the plenary debate. But we have unhappiness in Latvia. We have sorrow. The current Minister of Education of Latvia actually closed the schools of minorities with his reform, and this is the greatest disaster, which is not in line with the spirit, nature and letter of the European Union. And now we celebrate the centenary of the Free State of Latvia.  A hundred years ago, the Free State of Latvia was so democratic that it guaranteed education in eight languages in secondary schools, including Latvian. I now specifically speak Latvian, not French or English, to show that we Latvian Russians manage The Latvian language. But please, the European Union, Members, colleagues, support us! This is vital because we have the slogans "United in diversity!". United in diversity means that nations are more than states. Latvian Russians are part of Europe. Thank you!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Colleagues, we are done.
